Subject  :-
How to copy unversioned test resources during release:perform?  
Date  :-
Sat, 04 Jan 2014 15:22:10 GMT  
contents:- 
Hi&#010;&#010;I have a question about the release plugin.&#010;&#010;I have test resources which are not under version control. As testing is part &#010;of release:perform that fails without those resources.&#010;&#010;How can I tell Maven to copy those unversioned test resources into &#010;target/checkout/target/test-classes/. I really would prefer not to skip &#010;testing. Those test resource won't come into the public vcs as they have &#010;credentials for a webservice.&#010;&#010;Markus&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during release:perform?  
Date  :-
Sat, 04 Jan 2014 15:53:53 GMT  
contents:- 
Hi,&#010;&#010;This is probably not only an issue during a release, but also during  &#010;standard builds.&#010;Depending on where those test resource are, you could look at the  &#010;maven-scm-plugin[1] (private vcs) or&#010;wagon-maven-plugin.&#010;If this works for a usual build, it should work for the  &#010;maven-release-plugin as well.&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;[1] http://maven.apache.org/scm/maven-scm-plugin/&#010;[2] http://mojo.codehaus.org/wagon-maven-plugin/&#010;&#010;Op Sat, 04 Jan 2014 16:22:10 +0100 schreef Markus Malkusch  &#010;&lt;markus@malkusch.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hi&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have a question about the release plugin.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I have test resources which are not under version control. As testing is  &#010;&gt; part&#010;&gt; of release:perform that fails without those resources.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; How can I tell Maven to copy those unversioned test resources into&#010;&gt; target/checkout/target/test-classes/. I really would prefer not to skip&#010;&gt; testing. Those test resource won't come into the public vcs as they have&#010;&gt; credentials for a webservice.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Markus&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Markus Malkusch &lt;mar...@malkusch.de&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during  release:perform?  
Date  :-
Sat, 04 Jan 2014 16:24:34 GMT  
contents:- 
Robert Scholte:&#010;&#010;&gt; This is probably not only an issue during a release, but also during&#010;&gt; standard builds.&#010;&#010;It is only a issue during release:perform.&#010;&#010;release:perform checks out the tag which release:prepare made and does&#010;every operation (incl. testing) in this new copy. As the test resources&#010;are not in the vcs they are missing in the tag and testing fails.&#010;&#010;Markus&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :-

Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during  release:perform?  
Date  :-
Sat, 04 Jan 2014 16:41:05 GMT  
contents:- 
You don't have to explain the maven-release-plugin to me, I think I did  &#010;the 3 latest releases ;)&#010;&#010;In short: release:perform is the same as&#010;cd target/checkout&#010;mvn deploy (apart from some release specific arguments/configuration, if  &#010;these are there)&#010;&#010;This makes it a normal build again.&#010;For that reason: how are these test-resources retrieved during a normal  &#010;build?&#010;If this is automated, then the release:perform should work as well.&#010;&#010;So "How can I tell Maven to copy those unversioned test resources into  &#010;target/checkout/target/test-classes/."&#010;What's the origin of these sources?&#010;&#010;Stephens answer should work as well, although IMO it shouldn't matter if  &#010;it is a SNAPSHOT or non-SNAPSHOT build.&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;Op Sat, 04 Jan 2014 17:24:34 +0100 schreef Markus Malkusch  &#010;&lt;markus@malkusch.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Robert Scholte:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; This is probably not only an issue during a release, but also during&#010;&gt;&gt; standard builds.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; It is only a issue during release:perform.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; release:perform checks out the tag which release:prepare made and does&#010;&gt; every operation (incl. testing) in this new copy. As the test resources&#010;&gt; are not in the vcs they are missing in the tag and testing fails.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Markus&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Re: How to copy unversioned test resources during   release:perform?  
Date  :-
Sat, 04 Jan 2014 21:56:25 GMT  
contents:- 
Op Sat, 04 Jan 2014 21:29:02 +0100 schreef Markus Malkusch  &#010;&lt;markus@malkusch.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; Robert Scholte:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; In short: release:perform is the same as&#010;&gt;&gt; cd target/checkout&#010;&gt;&gt; mvn deploy (apart from some release specific arguments/configuration,&#010;&gt;&gt; if  these are there)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I thought release:perform is doing a checkout from the last vcs tag which&#010;&gt; was created by release:prepare.&#010;&#010;http://maven.apache.org/maven-release/maven-release-plugin/examples/perform-release.html&#010;Sure, checking out is the first step, but the next step is less magic then  &#010;most users think.&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Anyways, something is doing a checkout of the latest tag. My test  &#010;&gt; resources&#010;&gt; are not included in the vcs (as they have credentials). But that's all  &#010;&gt; fine&#010;&gt; and the way I want it.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I just need a way to copy those unversioned files from&#010;&gt; src/test/resources/ to target/checkout/target/test-classes/ before&#010;&gt; mvn:release is running test.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; For that reason: how are these test-resources retrieved during a normal  &#010;&gt;&gt;  build?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; They're in src/test/resources/ and everything works as usual. I guess  &#010;&gt; those&#010;&gt; resources are somewhere in maven's super pom defined.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Ok, so they are placed there manual, not really the Maven way.&#010;This means that a co-worker cannot check out the sources and run the tests  &#010;without getting the test-resources from...?&#010;Depending on your requirements I would suggest putting the test-sources  &#010;under a common folder like ${user.home}/myproject/test-resources and copy  &#010;them during process-test-resources[1] or use filtering[2].&#010;&#010;I'm just not a fan of a different build during release. There are too much  &#010;things that can go wrong.&#010;&#010;Robert&#010;&#010;[1]  &#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-resources-plugin/testResources-mojo.html&#010;[2]  &#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-resources-plugin/examples/filter.html&#010;&#010;or go for the quick solution of Stephen&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt; Stephens answer should work as well&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'll try that. I forgot that I already posted here and didn't subscribe&#010;&gt; so I read today the first time about it.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Markus&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Tommy Svensson &lt;to...@natusoft.se&gt;  
Subject  :-
Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 13:15:02 GMT  
contents:- 
I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned out&#010;to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&#010;Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&#010;- You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things you&#010;have no control over. &#010;- You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;- You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if you&#010;have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time. &#010;- Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom are no&#010;longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process. &#010;- After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and ”release” the artifacts before the become available. &#010;&#010;The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely brilliant&#010;idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other open source&#010;code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open source world&#010;(well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process to this central&#010;repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting the easy sharing&#010;of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks that are not available&#010;in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put up with this, which now&#010;also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to be changed to provide a&#010;trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or there need to be an alternative&#010;open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial for anyone to share their binaries&#010;for easy access by others. I’m wondering if I’m alone in this view or if there are others&#010;who agree with me ? &#010;&#010;Tommy Svensson&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;  

================

Re: Maven Central Opinion

Hi Tommy,&#010;&#010; &gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools&#010; &gt; at github to maven central.&#010;&#010;So just create a ticket on JIRA ...&#010;&#010; &gt; This turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&#010;Can you give a hint from where this "requirements" are comming from?&#010;&#010;I know of the following:&#010;&#010;https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide&#010;&#010;This is what i use...&#010;&#010;http://search.maven.org/#artifactdetails%7Ccom.soebes.smpp%7Csmpp%7C0.6.3%7Cpom&#010;&#010;I don't have Sontype pom as parent for example....&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit&#010; &gt; things you have no control over.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your&#010; &gt; software even if you have no idea if it will be&#010; &gt;  a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&#010;This is the basic workflow with Maven release plugin.&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point&#010; &gt;  out in your pom are no longer yours to decide over.&#010; &gt;  It will be updated during the submission process.&#010;&#010;Sure. During the release workflow a tag is created...&#010;&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to&#010; &gt;  login to Sonatypes nexus server and ”release” the artifacts before&#010; &gt;  the become available.&#010;&#010;Needed to promote the artifacts to Maven Central..&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself&#010; &gt;  is a completely brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level&#010; &gt; where anyone can just depend on other open source code and automatically&#010; &gt; download it on build. This is really good for the open source world&#010; &gt; (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it).&#010;&#010;Do you have something which is not Java/JVM based ? Like &#010;Ruby/Python/Perl/Whatever ?&#010;&#010; &gt; The&#010; &gt; fact that the release process to this central repository&#010; &gt;is far too complex, I see as a really great problem,&#010; &gt;inhibiting the easy sharing of open source work.&#010;&#010;The problem in earlier days where that it was too easy to put something &#010;on Maven central and the results have been:&#010;bad quality, many arfitacts which are not signed,&#010;containing repositories in the pom's which results in many problems and&#010;other problems...&#010;&#010; &gt; I have often found open source tools and frameworks that are not&#010; &gt; available in maven central, and that is because not everyone&#010; &gt;is willing to put up with this, which now also includes myself.&#010;&#010;The point in this is: To hold a quality level inside of Maven central.&#010;&#010;I think the price it's worth the effort. It's a real centralized area &#010;where everyone can get the artifacts from. If you use &#010;Maven/Gradle/BuildR/Ant+IVY/WhatEver etc.&#010;&#010; &gt;  As I see it, either this procedure needs to be changed to provide&#010; &gt;  a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms,&#010;&#010;What do you mean by "without affecting you poms?" During the release &#010;process the versions of your artifacts are being changed from &#010;X.Y-SNAPSHOT to X.Y so the pom's must be changed.&#010;&#010;May be i misundestand a thing here...&#010;&#010; &gt;  or there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease&#010; &gt;  of release, where it is trivial for anyone to share their binaries&#010; &gt; for easy access by others.&#010;&#010;Don't hesitate to make suggestions how to make it simpler and reliable &#010;too...&#010;&#010; &gt;  I’m wondering if I’m alone in this&#010; &gt;  view or if there are others who agree with me ?&#010;&#010;Unfortunately I don't, cause i know the drawbacks of a simpler &#010;procedure...but i'm willing to learn to get things better...&#010;&#010;Kind regards&#010;Karl Heinz Marbaise&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Adam Retter &lt;adam.ret...@googlemail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 14:31:30 GMT  
contents:- 
On the flip side - I would argue that the process is not too&#010;difficult. It is well documented and easy to understand, it can also&#010;be automated if you wish.&#010;&#010;You need not necessarily inherit the Sonatype pom, and if you do you&#010;can override whatever you like anyway.&#010;&#010;I think the current process means that artifacts that are released are&#010;well thought about and that their pom's provided a minimum of useful&#010;information.&#010;&#010;If you want to release something and you care about it, then I will&#010;assume that it is of good quality, then I would ask the question "Why&#010;should you care less about a high quality release than the code?"&#010;&#010;On 5 January 2014 13:15, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned&#010;out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things&#010;you have no control over.&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if&#010;you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom&#010;are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process.&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and ”release” the artifacts before the become available.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely&#010;brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other&#010;open source code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open&#010;source world (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process&#010;to this central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting&#010;the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks&#010;that are not available in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put&#010;up with this, which now also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to&#010;be changed to provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or&#010;there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial&#010;for anyone to share their binaries for easy access by others. I’m wondering if I’m alone&#010;in this view or if there are others who agree with me ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Adam Retter&#010;&#010;skype: adam.retter&#010;tweet: adamretter&#010;http://www.adamretter.org.uk&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Thomas Broyer &lt;t.bro...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 14:32:25 GMT  
contents:- 
On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 2:15 PM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven&#010;&gt; central. This turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to&#010;&gt; maven central:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus&#010;&gt; inherit things you have no control over.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Wrong. That POM only helps you having things setup properly, by configuring&#010;everything for you to fulfill the requirements without even thinking about&#010;it.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for&#010;&gt; such.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Wrong (see notes below about the maven-release-plugin and "the Maven Way™").&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your&#010;&gt; software even if you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new&#010;&gt; functionality at this point in time.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;If by "submission time" you mean "mvn release:prepare release:perform",&#010;then, well, you're releasing stuff so you'd better know how you want to&#010;call it "at that point in time".&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out&#010;&gt; in your pom are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during&#010;&gt; the submission process.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Wrong. This is a result of the maven-release-plugin and "the Maven Way™",&#010;but you're not forced to use it to release your artifacts. Some people just&#010;put non-SNAPSHOT version in their POM and then use "mvn deploy" to deploy&#010;to a Maven repo (such as Sonatype OSS); see&#010;https://github.com/resteasy/Resteasy/tree/master/jaxrs, they don't use&#010;snapshots.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to&#010;&gt; Sonatypes nexus server and ”release” the artifacts before the become&#010;&gt; available.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Yes, that's how it goes. The idea I think is that the artifacts are&#010;temporarily published in a special repository (this is called "staging") so&#010;you can update your POMs and test those artifacts before actually releasing&#010;them / pushing them to Central. Some people use that to make "release&#010;candidates": their stage artifacts, announce it on their project's mailing&#010;list and have people test the new thing, and after a few days, if nobody&#010;reported a blocking issue, they can just push the "release" button. I&#010;believe the Apache Foundation works that way (where people vote +1/0/-1 on&#010;the staged artifacts during a couple days to a week)&#010;I believe many other people just push the release button right away.&#010;Note that you can use the nexus-staging-maven-plugin in your POM to&#010;automatically close the staging repository (make it read-only) and even&#010;automatically release it afterwards:&#010;http://books.sonatype.com/nexus-book/reference/staging-sect-deployment.html#staging-sect-deployment-nexus-staging-maven-plugin&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself&#010;&gt; is a completely brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where&#010;&gt; anyone can just depend on other open source code and automatically download&#010;&gt; it on build. This is really good for the open source world (well, at least&#010;&gt; the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process to this&#010;&gt; central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem,&#010;&gt; inhibiting the easy sharing of open source work.&#010;&#010;&#010;Before going further, have you ever deployed artifacts to a repository?&#010;More than half of what you're ranting about is about releasing artifacts&#010;with Maven and deploying them to a repository, and more specifically about&#010;the maven-release-plugin (and many people hate it); only a couple points&#010;are about Sonatype OSS and Central.&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Thomas Broyer&#010;/tɔ.ma.bʁwa.je/ &lt;http://xn--nna.ma.xn--bwa-xxb.je/&gt;&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Stuart McCulloch &lt;mccu...@sonatype.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 14:36:08 GMT  
contents:- 
On 5 Jan 2014, at 13:15, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned&#010;out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&#010;[ disclaimer: I work at Sonatype ]&#010;&#010;Any suggestions for improving the process are welcome - most of the requirements below are&#010;actually more recommendations / effects of the maven-release-plugin workflow, so maybe we&#010;need to clarify this on the wiki.&#010;&#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things&#010;you have no control over. &#010;&#010;The wiki recommends a parent pom with the relevant distributionManagement (so Maven knows&#010;where to deploy artifacts) plus some release configuration for adding sources, javadoc, signatures,&#010;etc.&#010;&#010;You can always use a different parent pom and copy the distributionManagement section across&#010;- feel free to ask for help with this, and we can always add a section to the wiki if others&#010;would find this useful&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&#010;This is the standard Maven release workflow - you don’t strictly need this if you’re just&#010;uploading releases, just go to the existing tagged release and use “mvn deploy”&#010;&#010;(you’ll need override the deploy properties on the command line ie. http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-deploy-plugin/deploy-mojo.html#altDeploymentRepository&#010;if your pom doesn’t point to OSSRH)&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if&#010;you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&#010;&#010;As above, you can always deploy an existing release - either with “mvn deploy” or by packaging&#010;it up as a bundle and uploading it using the UI:&#010;&#010;    https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide#SonatypeOSSMavenRepositoryUsageGuide-UploadStagingBundle&#010;&#010;However, once you have released an artifact to central its content should never change&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom&#010;are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process. &#010;&#010;That’s the Maven release plugin - it updates the released pom so it points to the right&#010;tagged release, then changes it back for development&#010;&#010;Some projects do releases differently by using the versions plugin to update the poms, tagging&#010;the release manually, then finally using “mvn deploy"&#010;&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and ”release” the artifacts before the become available. &#010;&#010;That’s so you can check the uploaded artifacts before they get distributed to central, mirrors,&#010;and from there to developers machines - because once a release is on central its content should&#010;never change&#010;&#010;If you want to skip this step then you can by configuring the nexus-staging-maven-plugin which&#010;can help manage the staging workflow:&#010;&#010;    http://books.sonatype.com/nexus-book/reference/staging-sect-deployment.html#staging-sect-deployment-nexus-staging-maven-plugin&#010;&#010;    &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;      &lt;groupId&gt;org.sonatype.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;      &lt;artifactId&gt;nexus-staging-maven-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;      &lt;extensions&gt;true&lt;/extensions&gt;&#010;      &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;        &lt;releaseAfterClose&gt;true&lt;/releaseAfterClose&gt;&#010;      &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;    &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;You can also use this plugin to access the same staging commands available to you through&#010;the Nexus UI (or you could even use the underlying REST API if you wish)&#010;&#010;Finally depending on your project there are alternative routes to central, such as http://www.apache.org/dev/publishing-maven-artifacts.html&#010;for Apache projects, or the new https://bintray.com/ service. &#010;&#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely&#010;brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other&#010;open source code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open&#010;source world (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process&#010;to this central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting&#010;the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks&#010;that are not available in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put&#010;up with this, which now also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to&#010;be changed to provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or&#010;there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial&#010;for anyone to share their binaries for easy access by others. I’m wondering if I’m alone&#010;in this view or if there are others who agree with me ? &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Tommy Svensson &lt;to...@natusoft.se&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Mon, 06 Jan 2014 12:49:04 GMT  
contents:- 
Hello again,&#010;&#010;OK, I suspected that I get a lot of replies on this :-). &#010;&#010;From experience in other forums I also expected to have people tell me to go screw myself,&#010;but that has not happened. There are apparently only professionals here! That said, there&#010;some very good replies and explanations but also some I do react to.  &#010;&#010;I'll start with the latter. The arguments about quality I just don't buy. We are only talking&#010;poms here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about the quality of the software itself.&#010;What is really bothering me however is the argument that if you don't have your things in&#010;the way we think they should be, you are not serious enough. It hasn't been said straight&#010;out but implied. The word that pops into my head here is "Moralizing"! I take my work very&#010;seriously and I take my open source work even more seriously (since in that case I'm allowed&#010;the time for it :-)). That if I have one file that is not up to someones liking I'm not taking&#010;releasing of my software seriously is just absurd. &#010;_______&#010;&#010;From one of the replies:&#010;&gt; As I said in a previous message, deploying to the remote repo is just a&#010;&gt; matter of "mvn deploy", using either the maven-deploy-plugin (by default)&#010;&gt; or the nexus-staging-maven-plugin.&#010;&#010;That is good, that is how easy it should be!&#010;&#010;&gt; You'll have to configure the GPG plugin to sign your artifacts though, as&#010;&gt; it's a requirement to deploy to Central.&#010;&#010;No problem!&#010;&#010;I'm going to go though the documentation again and solve the "easy" way to do it :-).  And&#010;If I can't find a page that explains this clearly I will create such! I have gotten very much&#010;information here to go on. &#010;&#010;Someone also pointed out that local webserver repositories are good enough for "small" projects.&#010;I basically agree with that. I only considered maven central since someone asked me. But it&#010;is easier to have things in central and not have to add multiple repository specifications&#010;in your pom/settings. OK, you can use nexus to merge several repositories into one and then&#010;use that. But if submission to central can be made easy then it is worth to do it. Software&#010;does not have to be large apache projects to be useful. There are some truly useful software&#010;out there that comes from single individuals.&#010;________&#010;&#010;Here is my view of how I would want a maven repository to be:&#010;&#010;- No requirements of javadoc or sources. If you want to include those, no problem, but if&#010;you don't  it is up to you. Personally I like to have sources available in the repository&#010;for the third party software I'm using so I would also submit sources to my software, but&#010;that is entirely up to me.&#010;&#010;- Tags on submitted software (not required - can be empty). &#010;&#010;- Searchable data in addition to group and artifact:&#010;  - Tags&#010;  - Descriptions&#010;&#010;- A browsable (navigable) web gui, not just searches. &#010;&#010;- A standardized documentation zip containing PDFs and/or markdown.&#010;&#010;- Quality indication:&#010;  - The possibility to star artifacts just like you can star repos in github. Also for group&#010;level.&#010;  - Download statistics (filtered on ip-address, multiple downloads from the same ip-address&#010;only count as one).&#010;  - A quality value based on these two as sorting order for search results.&#010;&#010;- When an artifact or group is selected in the web gui the following should be displayed:&#010;  - Dependency tags for the artifact (obviously :-))&#010;  - Pom information like description, web url, developers, scm url, etc.&#010;  - Stars and download stats.&#010;  - Any submitted docs.&#010;&#010;With so much software available in one place it would be very nice to have it more searchable&#010;and on more useful criteria, and also to have the ability to get more details on the software&#010;at the same place.&#010;&#010;Tommy&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Adam Retter &lt;adam.ret...@googlemail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Mon, 06 Jan 2014 12:56:32 GMT  
contents:- 
&gt; I'll start with the latter. The arguments about quality I just don't buy. We are only&#010;talking poms here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about the quality of the software&#010;itself.&#010;&#010;I agree the pom says nothing about the quality of the software.&#010;However, having a standard mechanism for describing in small detail&#010;software releases. By ensuring that this is consistent, it ensures&#010;that the quality of searching for artifacts in Maven central is&#010;maintained, it also ensures that when someone finds an artifact they&#010;can look at the pom to see what it does and who to contact should they&#010;have a problem. I consider that a small investment.&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Adam Retter&#010;&#010;skype: adam.retter&#010;tweet: adamretter&#010;http://www.adamretter.org.uk&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Tamás Cservenák &lt;ta...@cservenak.net&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Mon, 06 Jan 2014 13:10:40 GMT  
contents:- 
&gt;&#010;&gt; The arguments about quality I just don't buy. We are only talking poms&#010;&gt; here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about the quality of the&#010;&gt; software itself.&#010;&#010;&#010;Quality of metadata. POM serve as "metadata" in this case, so, I'd rather&#010;say Central enforces quality of "metadata" (ie. POM properly "filled in",&#010;using proper and proven/owned groupId, sane artifactId, etc, minimal set of&#010;fields are given, file signatures, checksums are present, no update of&#010;already deployed stuff happens [ie. your deploy request would overwrite&#010;something in Cenral] etc).&#010;&#010;Still, you can deploy a jar full of zeroes to Central if you wish, all&#010;until you use proper GA, the checksums and signatures matches, and POM&#010;fulfills minimal requirements :)&#010;&#010;&#010;My 5 cents&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Tommy Svensson &lt;to...@natusoft.se&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Mon, 06 Jan 2014 13:23:04 GMT  
contents:- 
&#010;6 jan 2014 kl. 14:10 skrev Tamás Cservenák &lt;tamas@cservenak.net&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt; &#010;&gt;&gt; The arguments about quality I just don't buy. We are only talking poms&#010;&gt;&gt; here. Whatever is in the poms says nothing about the quality of the&#010;&gt;&gt; software itself.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Quality of metadata. POM serve as "metadata" in this case, so, I'd rather&#010;&gt; say Central enforces quality of "metadata" (ie. POM properly "filled in",&#010;&gt; using proper and proven/owned groupId, sane artifactId, etc, minimal set of&#010;&gt; fields are given, file signatures, checksums are present, no update of&#010;&gt; already deployed stuff happens [ie. your deploy request would overwrite&#010;&gt; something in Cenral] etc).&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Still, you can deploy a jar full of zeroes to Central if you wish, all&#010;&gt; until you use proper GA, the checksums and signatures matches, and POM&#010;&gt; fulfills minimal requirements :)&#010;&#010;And I think that is a good thing! It would be rather stupid to do that, but that is beside&#010;the point :-).&#010;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; My 5 cents&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Mon, 06 Jan 2014 15:52:41 GMT  
contents:- 
I am assuming that you are putting this in Central so I can easily use &#010;it without having to worry about the effect on my build process or &#010;without having to get into your sources and dependencies to build my app &#010;and I have appropriate license agreements included so I know what I am &#010;incorporating into my app.&#010;&#010;In that case, I would like you to follow the Maven "Best Practices" for &#010;deploying to Central.&#010;&#010;Using the Release plug-in may save you some steps if you do not already &#010;have a private repo for releasing software internally.&#010;It seems to me that if you are already "releasing" to your own repo &#010;prior to trying to upload it to Central, you are probably going to find &#010;that the Release plug-in is not the "best practice".&#010;We would be in the same situation if we ever decided to put some of our &#010;utilities into Maven Central. We have already done the release and our &#010;SCM is in the state in which we want it.&#010;We would probably have to look at our parent POM/child POM structure to &#010;be sure that it met Maven Central requirements.&#010;&#010;I think that you did the right thing by raising your concerns here and I &#010;think that you got some very good advice and concrete suggestions.&#010;&#010;This is a very good group that is usually well-mannered when approached &#010;in the way that you did.&#010;You were very clear about what you wanted to do and you raised very &#010;specified issues that you wanted to discuss.&#010;You also reacted to the advice in a positive way that encouraged a &#010;factual discussion rather than a personal attack.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 06/01/2014 7:49 AM, Tommy Svensson wrote:&#010;&gt; Hello again,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; OK, I suspected that I get a lot of replies on this :-).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  From experience in other forums I also expected to have people tell me to go screw myself,&#010;but that has not happened. There are apparently only professionals here! That said, there&#010;some very good replies and explanations but also some I do react to.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'll start with the latter. It hasn't been said straight&#010;out but implied. The word that pops into my head here is "Moralizing"! That if I have one file that is not up to someones liking I'm not taking&#010;releasing of my software seriously is just absurd.&#010;&gt; _______&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  From one of the replies:&#010;&gt;&gt; As I said in a previous message, deploying to the remote repo is just a&#010;&gt;&gt; matter of "mvn deploy", using either the maven-deploy-plugin (by default)&#010;&gt;&gt; or the nexus-staging-maven-plugin.&#010;&gt; That is good, that is how easy it should be!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; You'll have to configure the GPG plugin to sign your artifacts though, as&#010;&gt;&gt; it's a requirement to deploy to Central.&#010;&gt; No problem!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm going to go though the documentation again and solve the "easy" way to do it :-).&#010; And If I can't find a page that explains this clearly I will create such! I have gotten very&#010;much information here to go on.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Someone also pointed out that local webserver repositories are good enough for "small"&#010;projects. I basically agree with that. I only considered maven central since someone asked&#010;me. But it is easier to have things in central and not have to add multiple repository specifications&#010;in your pom/settings. OK, you can use nexus to merge several repositories into one and then&#010;use that. But if submission to central can be made easy then it is worth to do it. Software&#010;does not have to be large apache projects to be useful. There are some truly useful software&#010;out there that comes from single individuals.&#010;&gt; ________&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Here is my view of how I would want a maven repository to be:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - No requirements of javadoc or sources. If you want to include those, no problem, but&#010;if you don't  it is up to you. Personally I like to have sources available in the repository&#010;for the third party software I'm using so I would also submit sources to my software, but&#010;that is entirely up to me.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Tags on submitted software (not required - can be empty).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Searchable data in addition to group and artifact:&#010;&gt;    - Tags&#010;&gt;    - Descriptions&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - A browsable (navigable) web gui, not just searches.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - A standardized documentation zip containing PDFs and/or markdown.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - Quality indication:&#010;&gt;    - The possibility to star artifacts just like you can star repos in github. Also for&#010;group level.&#010;&gt;    - Download statistics (filtered on ip-address, multiple downloads from the same ip-address&#010;only count as one).&#010;&gt;    - A quality value based on these two as sorting order for search results.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; - When an artifact or group is selected in the web gui the following should be displayed:&#010;&gt;    - Dependency tags for the artifact (obviously :-))&#010;&gt;    - Pom information like description, web url, developers, scm url, etc.&#010;&gt;    - Stars and download stats.&#010;&gt;    - Any submitted docs.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; With so much software available in one place it would be very nice to have it more searchable&#010;and on more useful criteria, and also to have the ability to get more details on the software&#010;at the same place.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Tommy&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Markus Malkusch &lt;mar...@malkusch.de&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 14:39:07 GMT  
contents:- 
Tommy Svensson:&#010;&#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven&#010;&gt; central. This turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&#010;That was my first impression as well. But after reading the excellent&#010;documentation and setting everything properly up, I'm impressed how&#010;smooth releasing is.&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and&#010;&gt; thus inherit things you have no control over.&#010;&#010;I don't think that's a requirement. I think it's more a help to make&#010;releasing more easy for you.&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your&#010;&gt; software even if you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new&#010;&gt; functionality at this point in time.&#010;&#010;I always go the proposed minor version change. If I later decide to make &#010;a&#010;major change nobody prevents me to change the version at any time.&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point&#010;&gt; out in your pom are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated&#010;&gt; during the submission process.&#010;&#010;Yeah and that's really great. Without the release plugin I had to tag it&#010;myself. But AFAIK that's not a requirement for submitting a release to&#010;Maven Central.&#010;&#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to&#010;&gt; Sonatypes nexus server and ”release” the artifacts before the become&#010;&gt; available.&#010;&#010;You can configure the nexus-staging-maven-plugin to do that for you.&#010;autoReleaseAfterClose does that trick.&#010;&#010;My projects use a common parent pom (which itself uses the sonatype &#010;parent)&#010;where a typical release is done with two mvn commands and nothing more:&#010;mvn release:prepare and mvn release:perform. This releases to sonatype,&#010;tags a new version in vcs and makes a site-deploy to github. I'm really&#010;impressed how smooth things are.&#010;&#010;I understand that the process might look very complicated as first&#010;impression. But if you don't want to go it, you might ask the guy who&#010;opened the ticket to put your project into Maven Central:&#010;https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Uploading+3rd-party+Artifacts+to+The+Central+Repository&#010;&#010;Markus&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Markus Karg &lt;k...@quipsy.de&gt;  
Subject  :-
RE: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 15:18:42 GMT  
contents:- 
I uploaded lots of not-even-Mavenized prebuilt JARs to Maven Central and can tell you that&#010;you simply misunderstood these terms as "essential" requirements -- in fact most of them are&#010;only "best practices". You do neither need to have the Sonatype POM, it will just make things&#010;easier, nor do you have to use SNAPSHOTs. You can simply upload a prebuilt JAR file. The only&#010;"hard" requirements are a "good" POM, signing the JAR with GPG, uploading it to the OSS nexus&#010;instance, then closing and releasing it. This it at-most simple and done in minutes. If you&#010;need help, feel free to contact me at markus@headcrashing.eu, I can guide you.&#010;&#010;-----Original Message-----&#010;From: Tommy Svensson [mailto:tommy@natusoft.se] &#010;Sent: Sonntag, 5. Januar 2014 14:15&#010;To: Maven Users List&#010;Subject: Maven Central Opinion&#010;&#010;I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned out&#010;to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&#010;Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&#010;- You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things you&#010;have no control over. &#010;- You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;- You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if you&#010;have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time. &#010;- Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom are no&#010;longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process. &#010;- After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and "release" the artifacts before the become available. &#010;&#010;The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely brilliant&#010;idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other open source&#010;code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open source world&#010;(well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process to this central&#010;repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting the easy sharing&#010;of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks that are not available&#010;in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put up with this, which now&#010;also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to be changed to provide a&#010;trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or there need to be an alternative&#010;open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial for anyone to share their binaries&#010;for easy access by others. I'm wondering if I'm alone in this view or if there are others&#010;who agree with me ? &#010;&#010;Tommy Svensson&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Tommy Svensson &lt;to...@natusoft.se&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 16:29:41 GMT  
contents:- 
Well, I guess I have my answer, I am alone :-).&#010;&#010;Many people are telling me that both the sonatype super pom and SNAPSHOTs are optional. I&#010;obviously have been reading the wrong instructions. This is the instructions I've followed:&#010;&#010;&#010;&#009;https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide&#010;&#010;Are there better, clearer instructions somewhere else ? One of the "mvn release:*" commands&#010;(dont rember which ) failed if I did not have a SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was&#010;that I did not have a SNAPSHOT version. So is the above page completely wrong ? Are there&#010;other "mvn release:*" goals to run ? &#010;&#010;I also don't buy the argument that release complexity gives better quality. &#010;&#010;Many of the responses to my mail have also indicated that the update of my github repository&#010;is a totally obvious thing. I simply do not accept that. When I update my repository and what&#010;I update it with is my and only my decision! I went around this problem by making a copy repository&#010;before going through the release steps, and then deleted the copy afterwards, keeping my original&#010;intact. It was already in the state I wanted it before releasing to maven central. The only&#010;thing I want to release to maven central is binaries! My repository should not be touched.&#010;So if there is no way around that happening I guess I have released my first and last code&#010;to maven central.&#010;&#010;Anyhow, my question have been answered very clearly.&#010;&#010;Tommy&#010;&#010;&#010;5 jan 2014 kl. 16:18 skrev Markus Karg &lt;karg@quipsy.de&gt;:&#010;&#010;&gt; I uploaded lots of not-even-Mavenized prebuilt JARs to Maven Central and can tell you&#010;that you simply misunderstood these terms as "essential" requirements -- in fact most of them&#010;are only "best practices". You do neither need to have the Sonatype POM, it will just make&#010;things easier, nor do you have to use SNAPSHOTs. You can simply upload a prebuilt JAR file.&#010;The only "hard" requirements are a "good" POM, signing the JAR with GPG, uploading it to the&#010;OSS nexus instance, then closing and releasing it. This it at-most simple and done in minutes.&#010;If you need help, feel free to contact me at markus@headcrashing.eu, I can guide you.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -----Original Message-----&#010;&gt; From: Tommy Svensson [mailto:tommy@natusoft.se] &#010;&gt; Sent: Sonntag, 5. Januar 2014 14:15&#010;&gt; To: Maven Users List&#010;&gt; Subject: Maven Central Opinion&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This turned&#010;out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit things&#010;you have no control over. &#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even if&#010;you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&#010;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your pom&#010;are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process. &#010;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus server&#010;and "release" the artifacts before the become available. &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely&#010;brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other&#010;open source code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open&#010;source world (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process&#010;to this central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting&#010;the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks&#010;that are not available in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put&#010;up with this, which now also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to&#010;be changed to provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or&#010;there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial&#010;for anyone to share their binaries for easy access by others. I'm wondering if I'm alone in&#010;this view or if there are others who agree with me ? &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Benson Margulies &lt;bimargul...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 16:32:00 GMT  
contents:- 
Read section 7b of the page you link, it addresses your desires&#010;directly. I quote:&#010;&#010;You don't have to go through steps 7.a.1. through 7.a.3. if your&#010;artifacts have already been released or if you've generated your&#010;artifacts using something other than Maven.  The steps below allow you&#010;to skip using the maven-release-plugin entirely.  You can either use&#010;the maven-gpg-plugin to sign and deploy your artifacts or upload a&#010;staging bundle.&#010;&#010;On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 11:29 AM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Well, I guess I have my answer, I am alone :-).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many people are telling me that both the sonatype super pom and SNAPSHOTs are optional.&#010;I obviously have been reading the wrong instructions. This is the instructions I've followed:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;         https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Are there better, clearer instructions somewhere else ? One of the "mvn release:*" commands&#010;(dont rember which ) failed if I did not have a SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was&#010;that I did not have a SNAPSHOT version. So is the above page completely wrong ? Are there&#010;other "mvn release:*" goals to run ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I also don't buy the argument that release complexity gives better quality.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many of the responses to my mail have also indicated that the update of my github repository&#010;is a totally obvious thing. I simply do not accept that. When I update my repository and what&#010;I update it with is my and only my decision! I went around this problem by making a copy repository&#010;before going through the release steps, and then deleted the copy afterwards, keeping my original&#010;intact. It was already in the state I wanted it before releasing to maven central. The only&#010;thing I want to release to maven central is binaries! My repository should not be touched.&#010;So if there is no way around that happening I guess I have released my first and last code&#010;to maven central.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Anyhow, my question have been answered very clearly.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Tommy&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 5 jan 2014 kl. 16:18 skrev Markus Karg &lt;karg@quipsy.de&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I uploaded lots of not-even-Mavenized prebuilt JARs to Maven Central and can tell&#010;you that you simply misunderstood these terms as "essential" requirements -- in fact most&#010;of them are only "best practices". You do neither need to have the Sonatype POM, it will just&#010;make things easier, nor do you have to use SNAPSHOTs. You can simply upload a prebuilt JAR&#010;file. The only "hard" requirements are a "good" POM, signing the JAR with GPG, uploading it&#010;to the OSS nexus instance, then closing and releasing it. This it at-most simple and done&#010;in minutes. If you need help, feel free to contact me at markus@headcrashing.eu, I can guide&#010;you.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; -----Original Message-----&#010;&gt;&gt; From: Tommy Svensson [mailto:tommy@natusoft.se]&#010;&gt;&gt; Sent: Sonntag, 5. Januar 2014 14:15&#010;&gt;&gt; To: Maven Users List&#010;&gt;&gt; Subject: Maven Central Opinion&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven central. This&#010;turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to maven central:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and thus inherit&#010;things you have no control over.&#010;&gt;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&gt;&gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your software even&#010;if you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new functionality at this point in time.&#010;&gt;&gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out in your&#010;pom are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during the submission process.&#010;&gt;&gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to Sonatypes nexus&#010;server and "release" the artifacts before the become available.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself is a completely&#010;brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where anyone can just depend on other&#010;open source code and automatically download it on build. This is really good for the open&#010;source world (well, at least the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process&#010;to this central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem, inhibiting&#010;the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open source tools and frameworks&#010;that are not available in maven central, and that is because not everyone is willing to put&#010;up with this, which now also includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to&#010;be changed to provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms, or&#010;there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of release, where it is trivial&#010;for anyone to share their binaries for easy access by others. I'm wondering if I'm alone in&#010;this view or if there are others who agree with me ?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Thomas Broyer &lt;t.bro...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 20:06:27 GMT  
contents:- 
On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 5:29 PM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Well, I guess I have my answer, I am alone :-).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many people are telling me that both the sonatype super pom and SNAPSHOTs&#010;&gt; are optional. I obviously have been reading the wrong instructions.&#010;&#010;&#010;Maven dependency versionning is based on snapshots and releases, with&#010;releases that cannot change once published (if you messed up with your 1.0,&#010;you have to release a 1.0.1 (or whatever version you want))&#010;That doesn't mean you *have* to publish snapshots, and that doesn't even&#010;mean you have to use snapshot versions in your POM.&#010;But consider the pros and cons of not using snapshots: if your POM doesn't&#010;use a snapshot version, then anyone cloning your repo and doing a "mvn&#010;install" will have in its local repo the artifact it just built, and then&#010;when you publish that release yourself, that developer won't see it&#010;(because Maven won't check for a more recent version: non-snapshot versions&#010;do not change from Maven point of view – OK, it might no longer be true&#010;with recent versions of Maven, where the version is tied to the repo it&#010;comes from, IIRC).&#010;&#010;I agree the doc is strongly biased towards using sonatype-parent though,&#010;but as others pointed out, this is not a requirement (see&#010;https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide#SonatypeOSSMavenRepositoryUsageGuide-6.CentralSyncRequirement&#010;)&#010;&#010;I think the doc is for people who don't really know what they're doing and&#010;don't really want to know and just want to proceed, and sonatype-parent and&#010;the maven-release-plugin make it really easier for them.&#010;If you don't want to use the sonatype-parent parent, then you'll have to&#010;invest time into understanding what you have to do ("Central Sync&#010;Requirement") and how to configure your POM to achieve it.&#010;Similarly if you don't want to use the maven-release-plugin.&#010;&#010;Are there better, clearer instructions somewhere else ? One of the "mvn&#010;&gt; release:*" commands (dont rember which ) failed if I did not have a&#010;&gt; SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was that I did not have a SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt; version. So is the above page completely wrong ? Are there other "mvn&#010;&gt; release:*" goals to run ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;The maven-release-plugin is *one* way (the preferred way) to release&#010;artifacts, but it's actually only a big workflow that calls into other&#010;plugins: update the POMs with a non-snapshot version, verify that it&#010;builds, commit the change and tag the commit, deploy to the remote repo,&#010;then change the POMs to a snapshot version, verify that it builds, and&#010;commit the change.&#010;You're not forced to use the maven-release-plugin to release artifacts, you&#010;can do some or all of the above steps "by hand", and you could use&#010;non-snapshot versions all the time (but then you *cannot* use the&#010;maven-release-plugin).&#010;&#010;Again, the maven-release-plugin makes it simpler if you follow the rules&#010;(use snapshot versions) and accept the conditions; you're not forced to use&#010;it but you'll have to invest time into understanding what it does (that is&#010;mandatory or optional) and how to do (some of) it by other means.&#010;&#010;As I said in a previous message, deploying to the remote repo is just a&#010;matter of "mvn deploy", using either the maven-deploy-plugin (by default)&#010;or the nexus-staging-maven-plugin.&#010;You'll have to configure the GPG plugin to sign your artifacts though, as&#010;it's a requirement to deploy to Central.&#010;&#010;I bet you'll find many blogs online about how to do releases without the&#010;maven-release-plugin, and how to then deploy to Central.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Many of the responses to my mail have also indicated that the update of my&#010;&gt; github repository is a totally obvious thing. I simply do not accept that.&#010;&gt; When I update my repository and what I update it with is my and only my&#010;&gt; decision! I went around this problem by making a copy repository before&#010;&gt; going through the release steps, and then deleted the copy afterwards,&#010;&gt; keeping my original intact. It was already in the state I wanted it before&#010;&gt; releasing to maven central. The only thing I want to release to maven&#010;&gt; central is binaries! My repository should not be touched. So if there is no&#010;&gt; way around that happening I guess I have released my first and last code to&#010;&gt; maven central.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;The maven-release-plugin has many configuration properties related to SCM:&#010;whether to push changes, tag changes, etc.&#010;http://maven.apache.org/maven-release/maven-release-plugin/prepare-mojo.html&#010;&#010;Note, I never tried it but you could apparently just do "mvn&#010;release:perform -DconnectionUrl=…" (or creating a release.properties file&#010;and then using "mvn release:perform"):&#010;http://maven.apache.org/maven-release/maven-release-plugin/examples/perform-release.html&#010;&#010;

Hi Tommy,&#010;&#010;&gt; One of the "mvn release:*" commands (dont rember which ) failed if I&#010;&gt; did not have a SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was that I did&#010;&gt; not have a SNAPSHOT version.&#010;&#010;I did not notice any other reply specifically troubleshooting this problem,&#010;so... my guess is that you have a SNAPSHOT dependency in your dependency&#010;hierarchy. You cannot cut a release unless it only depends on releases.&#010;Otherwise, the behavior of the release could change out from under you&#010;if/when that SNAPSHOT version is updated.&#010;&#010;If you share the exact error message you received, others can assist in&#010;more detail.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Curtis&#010;&#010;&#010;On Sun, Jan 5, 2014 at 10:29 AM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Well, I guess I have my answer, I am alone :-).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many people are telling me that both the sonatype super pom and SNAPSHOTs&#010;&gt; are optional. I obviously have been reading the wrong instructions. This is&#010;&gt; the instructions I've followed:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; https://docs.sonatype.org/display/Repository/Sonatype+OSS+Maven+Repository+Usage+Guide&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Are there better, clearer instructions somewhere else ? One of the "mvn&#010;&gt; release:*" commands (dont rember which ) failed if I did not have a&#010;&gt; SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was that I did not have a SNAPSHOT&#010;&gt; version. So is the above page completely wrong ? Are there other "mvn&#010;&gt; release:*" goals to run ?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I also don't buy the argument that release complexity gives better quality.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Many of the responses to my mail have also indicated that the update of my&#010;&gt; github repository is a totally obvious thing. I simply do not accept that.&#010;&gt; When I update my repository and what I update it with is my and only my&#010;&gt; decision! I went around this problem by making a copy repository before&#010;&gt; going through the release steps, and then deleted the copy afterwards,&#010;&gt; keeping my original intact. It was already in the state I wanted it before&#010;&gt; releasing to maven central. The only thing I want to release to maven&#010;&gt; central is binaries! My repository should not be touched. So if there is no&#010;&gt; way around that happening I guess I have released my first and last code to&#010;&gt; maven central.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Anyhow, my question have been answered very clearly.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Tommy&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; 5 jan 2014 kl. 16:18 skrev Markus Karg &lt;karg@quipsy.de&gt;:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I uploaded lots of not-even-Mavenized prebuilt JARs to Maven Central and&#010;&gt; can tell you that you simply misunderstood these terms as "essential"&#010;&gt; requirements -- in fact most of them are only "best practices". You do&#010;&gt; neither need to have the Sonatype POM, it will just make things easier, nor&#010;&gt; do you have to use SNAPSHOTs. You can simply upload a prebuilt JAR file.&#010;&gt; The only "hard" requirements are a "good" POM, signing the JAR with GPG,&#010;&gt; uploading it to the OSS nexus instance, then closing and releasing it. This&#010;&gt; it at-most simple and done in minutes. If you need help, feel free to&#010;&gt; contact me at markus@headcrashing.eu, I can guide you.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; -----Original Message-----&#010;&gt; &gt; From: Tommy Svensson [mailto:tommy@natusoft.se]&#010;&gt; &gt; Sent: Sonntag, 5. Januar 2014 14:15&#010;&gt; &gt; To: Maven Users List&#010;&gt; &gt; Subject: Maven Central Opinion&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; I was asked to submit one of my opensource tools at github to maven&#010;&gt; central. This turned out to be a rather complex procedure.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Sonatype puts the following requirements on anyone wanting to submit to&#010;&gt; maven central:&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; - You are forced to set a Sonatype pom as parent of your project and&#010;&gt; thus inherit things you have no control over.&#010;&gt; &gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for&#010;&gt; such.&#010;&gt; &gt; - You are forced at submission time to select a new version for your&#010;&gt; software even if you have no idea if it will be a minor, bugfix or new&#010;&gt; functionality at this point in time.&#010;&gt; &gt; - Your public repository (github, etc) which you are forced to point out&#010;&gt; in your pom are no longer yours to decide over. It will be updated during&#010;&gt; the submission process.&#010;&gt; &gt; - After running 3 different mvn commands you also need to login to&#010;&gt; Sonatypes nexus server and "release" the artifacts before the become&#010;&gt; available.&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; The idea of the maven repository that has grown larger than maven itself&#010;&gt; is a completely brilliant idea. It takes open source to a new level where&#010;&gt; anyone can just depend on other open source code and automatically download&#010;&gt; it on build. This is really good for the open source world (well, at least&#010;&gt; the Java/JVM part of it) . The fact that the release process to this&#010;&gt; central repository is far too complex, I see as a really great problem,&#010;&gt; inhibiting the easy sharing of open source work. I have often found open&#010;&gt; source tools and frameworks that are not available in maven central, and&#010;&gt; that is because not everyone is willing to put up with this, which now also&#010;&gt; includes myself. As I see it, either this procedure needs to be changed to&#010;&gt; provide a trivial release of binary artifacts without affecting your poms,&#010;&gt; or there need to be an alternative open repository providing ease of&#010;&gt; release, where it is trivial for anyone to share their binaries for easy&#010;&gt; access by others. I'm wondering if I'm alone in this view or if there are&#010;&gt; others who agree with me ?&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; Tommy Svensson&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt; &gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

contents:- 
On 6 January 2014 06:48, Curtis Rueden &lt;ctrueden@wisc.edu&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi Tommy,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; One of the "mvn release:*" commands (dont rember which ) failed if I&#010;&gt;&gt; did not have a SNAPSHOT version and told me the problem was that I did&#010;&gt;&gt; not have a SNAPSHOT version.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I did not notice any other reply specifically troubleshooting this problem,&#010;&gt; so... my guess is that you have a SNAPSHOT dependency in your dependency&#010;&gt; hierarchy. You cannot cut a release unless it only depends on releases.&#010;&gt; Otherwise, the behavior of the release could change out from under you&#010;&gt; if/when that SNAPSHOT version is updated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; If you share the exact error message you received, others can assist in&#010;&gt; more detail.&#010;&#010;Tommy originally said "- You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version&#010;even if you have no use for such."&#010;So I believe that the release plugin is failing because he doesn't&#010;have a -SNAPSHOT in his pom.&#010;The release plugin checks that your artifact has a -SNAPSHOT version&#010;before it starts the workflow.&#010;If there is no -SNAPSHOT it assumes the artifact is already released&#010;and so stops.&#010;&#010;As others have already said, if that is not your workflow you need to&#010;do the stuff manually instead.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Graham Leggett &lt;minf...@sharp.fm&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven Central Opinion  
Date  :-
Sun, 05 Jan 2014 16:55:47 GMT  
contents:- 
On 05 Jan 2014, at 3:15 PM, Tommy Svensson &lt;tommy@natusoft.se&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; - You are forced to have a SNAPSHOT version even if you have no use for such.&#010;&#010;Maven works because there is a consistent level of standards and a consistent methodology,&#010;and these standards are enforced in central. If you pick and choose to ignore standards, you&#010;put the quality level of central at risk.&#010;&#010;Snapshots and releases are a fundamental part of maven, the maven system doesn't work without&#010;it. It is entirely right that central should block projects that refuse to follow the rules.&#010;&#010;Regards,&#010;Graham&#010;--&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;
