&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/cargo/extensions/trunk/maven2/plugin/src/main/java/org/codehaus/cargo/maven2/AbstractCargoMojo.java&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; for example), but what happens is that if a user unwillingly&#010;puts a&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't&#010;stop.&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works&#010;(even&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;       &lt;foo&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         bar&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;       &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is&#010;an&#010;&gt; unknown&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; parameter?&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Please advise&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thank you&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; S. Ali Tokmen&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; http://ali.tokmen.com/&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; My IM, GSM, PGP and other contact details&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; are on http://contact.ali.tokmen.com&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; --&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Baptiste &lt;Batmat&gt; MATHUS - http://batmat.net&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Sauvez un arbre,&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Mangez un castor ! nbsp;! &lt;users-help@maven.apache.org&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; &gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven2/Maven3 plugin development: Ensuring only the available parameters are allowed  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 19:12:23 GMT  
contents:- 
There are valid reasons why a configuration having "invalid" elements may&#010;be "valid".&#010;&#010;Consider the case where&#010;xpath:/project/build/pluginManagement/plugins/plugin/version specifies the&#010;*default* version and xpath:/project/build/plugins/plugin/version is&#010;absent... In this case xpath:/project/build/plugins/plugin/configuration&#010;applies to any version of the plugin, so somebody invoking a specific&#010;version of the plugin directly would/should get that configuration... Thus&#010;an element that does not make sense to the executing version of the plugin&#010;*may* make sense to a future/older version if the plugin... Hence failing&#010;because of unknown parameters would be a "bad thing"&#010;&#010;You could request the dom node yourself and parse it by hand if you want to&#010;issue warning though&#010;&#010;On Tuesday, 7 January 2014, S. Ali Tokmen wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Dear Maven users&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am one of the owners of Codehaus CARGO, which has a Maven2/Maven3&#010;&gt; plugin; and would have a question with regards to how parameters are&#010;&gt; managed.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We defined our MOJOs with parameters (you can see&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/cargo/extensions/trunk/maven2/plugin/src/main/java/org/codehaus/cargo/maven2/AbstractCargoMojo.java&#010;&gt; for example), but what happens is that if a user unwillingly puts a&#010;&gt; parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't stop.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works (even&#010;&gt; thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;foo&gt;&#010;&gt;         bar&#010;&gt;       &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is an unknown&#010;&gt; parameter?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Please advise&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; S. Ali Tokmen&#010;&gt; http://ali.tokmen.com/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My IM, GSM, PGP and other contact details&#010;&gt; are on http://contact.ali.tokmen.com&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org &lt;javascript:;&gt;&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&lt;javascript:;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Sent from my phone&#010;&#010;

Re: Maven2/Maven3 plugin development: Ensuring only the available parameters are allowed  
Date  :-
Tue, 14 Jan 2014 13:34:08 GMT  
contents:- 
Isn't that simply because the &lt;configuration&gt; is shared by all goals? (or&#010;all goals of the parent &lt;execution&gt;)&#010;&#010;&#010;On Tue, Jan 7, 2014 at 7:38 PM, S. Ali Tokmen &lt;nospam@alishomepage.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Dear Maven users&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am one of the owners of Codehaus CARGO, which has a Maven2/Maven3&#010;&gt; plugin; and would have a question with regards to how parameters are&#010;&gt; managed.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We defined our MOJOs with parameters (you can see&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; http://svn.codehaus.org/cargo/extensions/trunk/maven2/plugin/src/main/java/org/codehaus/cargo/maven2/AbstractCargoMojo.java&#010;&gt; for example), but what happens is that if a user unwillingly puts a&#010;&gt; parameter in the wrong place then the plugin execution doesn't stop.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As an example, I can write the below POM and build still works (even&#010;&gt; thought the MOJO has no parameter called "foo"):&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;groupId&gt;org.codehaus.cargo&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;artifactId&gt;cargo-maven2-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;version&gt;1.4.6&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;foo&gt;&#010;&gt;         bar&#010;&gt;       &lt;/foo&gt;&#010;&gt;     &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;   &lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there any way I can instruct by MOJO to fail if there is an unknown&#010;&gt; parameter?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Please advise&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thank you&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; S. Ali Tokmen&#010;&gt; http://ali.tokmen.com/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My IM, GSM, PGP and other contact details&#010;&gt; are on http://contact.ali.tokmen.com&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Thomas Broyer&#010;/tɔ.ma.bʁwa.je/ &lt;http://xn--nna.ma.xn--bwa-xxb.je/&gt;&#010;&#010;

I just need&#010;to be able to programmatically build a project from a pom file in order to&#010;retrieve its relevant information. I am not using, nor want to, a maven&#010;plugin, just need this functionality as part of my application.&#010;&#010;I've tried the code you successfully got to work but no luck so far. I still&#010;get the "mavenTools: null" from the repositoryManager being null. Am I&#010;missing something? Should I run this on some kind of special environment?&#010;&#010;I'd appreciate any help as I'm really lost here.&#010;&#010;Thanks in advance.&#010;&#010;&#010;Max Spring wrote&#010;&gt; Yes, having a projectBuilder in the Mojo did the trick.&#010;&gt; Thank you!&#010;&gt; The complete working example is down below.&#010;&gt; -Max&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; package org.example;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; import java.io.File;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.model.Model;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.model.building.ModelBuildingRequest;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.plugin.AbstractMojo;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.plugin.MojoExecutionException;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.project.DefaultProjectBuildingRequest;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.project.MavenProject;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuilder;&#010;&gt; import org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuildingResult;&#010;&gt; import org.sonatype.aether.RepositorySystemSession;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; /**&#010;&gt;   * run with: mvn $groupId:$artifactId:$version:fetch-pom&#010;&gt; -DpomFile=$pomFile&#010;&gt;   *&#010;&gt;   * @goal fetch-pom&#010;&gt;   */&#010;&gt; public class FetchModelMojo extends AbstractMojo{&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;    /**&#010;&gt;     * Current repository/network configuration of Maven.&#010;&gt;     * @parameter default-value="${repositorySystemSession}"&#010;&gt;     * @readonly&#010;&gt;     */&#010;&gt;    private RepositorySystemSession repoSession;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;    /**&#010;&gt;     * @component&#010;&gt;     */&#010;&gt;    private ProjectBuilder projectBuilder;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;    /**&#010;&gt;     * @parameter expression="${pomFile}" default-value=""&#010;&gt;     */&#010;&gt;    private String pomFile;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;    public void execute() throws MojoExecutionException {&#010;&gt;      try {&#010;&gt;        DefaultProjectBuildingRequest req = new&#010;&gt; DefaultProjectBuildingRequest();&#010;&gt;        req.setRepositorySession(repoSession);&#010;&gt;       &#010;&gt; req.setValidationLevel(ModelBuildingRequest.VALIDATION_LEVEL_STRICT);&#010;&gt;        ProjectBuildingResult res = projectBuilder.build(new&#010;&gt; File(pomFile),req);&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt;        // do something with the project&#010;&gt;        MavenProject prj = res.getProject();&#010;&gt;        System.out.println("prj=" + prj);&#010;&gt;        Model model = prj.getModel();&#010;&gt;        System.out.println("id="+model.getId());&#010;&gt;      } catch (Exception e) {&#010;&gt;        throw new MojoExecutionException(e.getMessage(), e);&#010;&gt;      }&#010;&gt;    }&#010;&gt; }&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; On 02/10/2012 01:19 PM, Olivier Lamy wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; You must probably use:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;      /**&#010;&gt;&gt;       * @component&#010;&gt;&gt;       */&#010;&gt;&gt;      private ProjectBuilder projectBuilder;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; 2012/2/10 Max Spring&amp;lt;&#010;&#010;&gt; m2spring@&#010;&#010;&gt; &amp;gt;:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm running into the same "mavenTools: null" problem, but my code sits&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; in a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven 3.0.3 mojo:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   public class MyMojo extends AbstractMojo{&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     /** @parameter default-value="${repositorySystemSession}" */&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     private RepositorySystemSession repoSession;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     public void execute() throws MojoExecutionException{&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       DefaultProjectBuilder builder = new DefaultProjectBuilder();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       DefaultProjectBuildingRequest req = new&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; DefaultProjectBuildingRequest();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       req.setRepositorySession(repoSession);&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       builder.build(new File("my-pom.xml"),req);&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       MavenProject prj = req.getProject();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;       Model model = prj.getModel();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     }&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   }&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; It barfs with&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;   Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: mavenTools: null&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     at org.apache.maven.project.MavenProject.&#010;&gt; &lt;init&gt;&#010;&gt; (MavenProject.java:249)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     at&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; org.apache.maven.project.DefaultProjectBuilder.build(DefaultProjectBuilder.java:128)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     at&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; org.apache.maven.project.DefaultProjectBuilder.build(DefaultProjectBuilder.java:102)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     at MyMojo.execute(MyMojo.java:59)&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; This is because repositorySystem in DefaultProjectBuilder is null, i.e.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; hasn't been injected:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     @Requirement&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;     private RepositorySystem repositorySystem;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; How can I get the right repositorySystem injected?&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Context:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'm essentially trying to do the M2E "Import Project" use case, but&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; completely outside of Eclipse.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; I want to populate a workspace using the SCM pointer given by a POM&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; fetched&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; from the group repository.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; -Max&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; On 10/18/2011 04:59 AM, Barrie Treloar wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; On Tue, Oct 18, 2011 at 10:02 PM, deusaquilus&amp;lt;&#010;&#010;&gt; deusaquilus@&#010;&#010;&gt; &amp;gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;   wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Here's what I'm doing:&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; File pom = new File("pom.xml");&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; DefaultProjectBuildingRequest request = new&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; DefaultProjectBuildingRequest();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; DefaultProjectBuilder builder = new DefaultProjectBuilder();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; String mavenHome = System.getenv("M2_HOME");&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ArtifactRepository localRepository = new MavenArtifactRepository(&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         "local",&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         new File(mavenHome +&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; "/repository").toURI().toURL().toString(),&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         new DefaultRepositoryLayout(),&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         new ArtifactRepositoryPolicy(),&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;         new ArtifactRepositoryPolicy());&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; request.setLocalRepository(localRepository);&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; MavenProject project = builder.build(pom, request).getProject();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Properties properties = project.getProperties();&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Trouble is it's giving me errors with "mavenTools: null"&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'd be surprised if that worked.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven makes heavy use of dependency injection via Plexus and chances&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; are you haven't set up some component that is being used.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; What is your actual use case.  I dont see why you would want to expose&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven properties as a Java properties object...&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Programmatically-get-maven-properties-tp4912280p5780906.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: DefaultProjectBuilder ... mavenTools: null [Was: Re: Programmatically get maven properties]  
Date  :-
Tue, 07 Jan 2014 23:25:06 GMT  
contents:- 
On 8 January 2014 09:00, juliangeo &lt;julianhernandeze@gmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Hi!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm new to Maven and I've been struggling with this for a while. I just need&#010;&gt; to be able to programmatically build a project from a pom file in order to&#010;&gt; retrieve its relevant information. I am not using, nor want to, a maven&#010;&gt; plugin, just need this functionality as part of my application.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I've tried the code you successfully got to work but no luck so far. I still&#010;&gt; get the "mavenTools: null" from the repositoryManager being null. Am I&#010;&gt; missing something? Should I run this on some kind of special environment?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'd appreciate any help as I'm really lost here.&#010;[del]&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; I'd be surprised if that worked.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; Maven makes heavy use of dependency injection via Plexus and chances&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt; are you haven't set up some component that is being used.&#010;&#010;Your answer is already here.&#010;&#010;You just can't use the classes outside of the Maven environment&#010;without also setting up all the other dependencies that are needed by&#010;that class.&#010;And as noted, this is done by Dependency Injection (via Plexus).&#010;You will need to look at MavenArtifactRepository and see what other&#010;objects need to be instantiated and set into it for it to work&#010;properly.&#010;&#010;Your use case is not something others are really trying to do, so you&#010;are unlikely to find someone with the knowledge to help.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Subject  :-
Maven install phase - Access is denied  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 04:29:45 GMT  
contents:- 
Hi all,&#010;&#010;I have a project which maven generates the following output in the target&#010;folder;&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\&lt;projectname&gt;.jar&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\&lt;projectname&gt;-sources.jar&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\installer\folder&#010;&#010;The above installer\folder is basically an empty folder which contains&#010;subfolders to be part of installer.&#010;&#010;&#010;I have a Build Error that displays "/Error installing artifact:&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\installer\folder (Access is denied)/"&#010;when executing *mvn clean install*.&#010; &#010;The maven copies the &lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\&lt;projectname&gt;.jar, &#010;&#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\&lt;projectname&gt;-sources.jar into local&#010;repository with success. However the maven attempts to copy the &#010;&lt;drive&gt;\projects\mywork\trunk\target\installer\folder into the local&#010;repository which is not I want to. This cause maven to throw the Build&#010;Error.&#010;&#010;How do I prevent maven copying the empty folder into local/remote repository&#010;as an artifact?&#010;&#010;Thanks,&#010;Andrew&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Maven-install-phase-Access-is-denied-tp5780920.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/artifactItems&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;outputDirectory&gt;${install4j_path}&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;overWriteReleases&gt;false&lt;/overWriteReleases&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;overWriteSnapshots&gt;true&lt;/overWriteSnapshots&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;execution&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;phase&gt;process-sources&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;goals&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;goal&gt;copy-dependencies&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;outputDirectory&gt;${basedir}/target/dependency&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;stripVersion&gt;true&lt;/stripVersion&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;overWriteIfNewer&gt;true&lt;/overWriteIfNewer&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;artifactId&gt;maven-assembly-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;version&gt;2.4&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;executions&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;execution&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;id&gt;make-assembly&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;phase&gt;package&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;goals&gt;&#010;&#00 Name  :- 
Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven install phase - Access is denied  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 22:57:05 GMT  
contents:- 
On 9 January 2014 06:56, andre999 &lt;andre999@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; &lt;build&gt;&#010;[del]&#010;&gt;                         &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-install-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;version&gt;2.5.1&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;                         &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;file&gt;certloader-custom-action.jar&lt;/file&gt;&#010;&gt;                                 &lt;file&gt;certloader-custom-action-sources.jar&lt;/file&gt;&#010;&#010;What do you expect this section to do?&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-install-plugin/install-mojo.html&#010;does not have a file property.&#010;And file implies a single entry, specifying it a second time would&#010;mean you overwrite the previous value.&#010;Lists are normally plural. (something like&#010;&lt;files&gt;&lt;file&gt;A&lt;/file&gt;&lt;file&gt;B&lt;/file&gt;&lt;/files&gt;&#010;&#010;If you want the sources to also be installed use the source plugin&#010;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-source-plugin/&#010;&#010;You shouldn't need this section on install at all.&#010;&#010;I can't see anything in that pom that would mean a directory is being&#010;installed into your local m2 cache.&#010;&#010;The assembly plugin can have these types of issues when you specify&#010;"dir" as a distribution format on deploy.&#010;But deploy is after install so this is not the problem.&#010;&#010;The problem I have is that it is trying to install&#010;P:\Projects\HlkProjects\CertLoader\hlk-certloader\trunk\target\install4j\certImport&#010;to&#010;P:\.m2\repository\net\healthlink\certloader\hlk-certloader\1.0.2-SNAPSHOT\lk-certloader-1.0.2-SNAPSHOT-certImport&#010;&#010;Why is maven attaching \target\install4j\certImport as a build&#010;artifact that it thinks it needs to install.&#010;&#010;Try running mvn -X and redirect the output to a file.&#010;Then search for target\install4j\certImport and see which plugin is&#010;being configured with this value.&#010;That might give you a hint as to where to look to turn that off.&#010;I'd almost suspect the parent pom.&#010;Using resources:copy-resource does not attach anything to be installed&#010;and it is the only thing that is using target\install4j\certImport&#010;from your supplied output.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
andre999 &lt;andre...@hotmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Maven install phase - Access is denied  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 21:28:17 GMT  
contents:- 
Thanks for the input. Apologies for the goose chase. I have found that there&#010;is an element &lt;attach&gt;true&lt;/attach&gt; property in the&#010;&lt;artifactId&gt;maven-install4j-plugin&lt;artifactId&gt;, which I did not include in&#010;this thread.&#010;&#010;With the &lt;attach&gt; set to false, the maven install has stopped reading any&#010;resources from the "install4j/certImport" folder, and copying resource into&#010;repository. &#010;&#010;Thanks again.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Maven-install-phase-Access-is-denied-tp5780920p5781054.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Le 8 janv. 2014 20:39, "andre999" &lt;andre999@hotmail.com&gt; a écrit :&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException:&#010;&gt;&#010;P:\Projects\HlkProjects\CertLoader\hlk-certloader\trunk\target\install4j\certImport&#010;&gt; (Access is denied)&#010;&gt;         at java.io.FileInputStream.open(Native Method)&#010;&#010;Isn't the problem that you're trying to install a directory rather than a&#010;file? I don't think that's possible, a folder is not an artifact, it has to&#010;be archived somehow first.&#010;&#010;

I suspect it has to do with your customization of the install goal:&#010;&#010;&gt; &#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt; &#009;&#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;groupId&gt;org.apache.maven.plugins&lt;/groupId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &#009;&#009;&lt;artifactId&gt;maven-install-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;          &#009;&#009;&lt;version&gt;2.5.1&lt;/version&gt;&#010;&gt;          &#009;&#009;&lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;          &#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;file&gt;certloader-custom-action.jar&lt;/file&gt;&#010;&gt;          &#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;file&gt;certloader-custom-action-sources.jar&lt;/file&gt;&#010;&gt;          &#009;&#009;&lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt; &#009;&#009;&#009;&lt;/plugin&gt;&#010;&#010;It looks as though your customization is telling it to install something that would not be&#010;installed by default.&#010;&#010;On Jan 8, 2014, at 4:33 PM, andre999 &lt;andre999@hotmail.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; That's the problem. Name  :- 
&quot;Weston, Steve&quot; &lt;Steve.Wes...@perceptive.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
release-plugin non-interactive release and system properties  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 13:11:23 GMT  
contents:- 
I'm confused as to how the version number in a pom file and the system properties like -DdevelopmentVersion=2.0-SNAPSHOT&#010;and -DreleaseVersion=1.2&#010;&#010;interact.&#010;When I run a mvn -B release:prepare -DdryRun=true -Dtag=1.2 -DdevelopmentVersion=2.0-SNAPSHOT&#010;-DreleaseVersion=1.2 for a pom.xml where &lt;version&gt;1.0&lt;/version&gt; and &lt;packaging&gt;jar&lt;/packaging&gt;&#010;the resulting jar file uses the pom version number not the command line version, i.e xxx-1.0.jar&#010;. Is this expected behaviour and if so what is the point of specifying the versions on the&#010;command line ?&#010;&#010;Steve Weston&#010;Principal Software Engineer&#010;&#010;PAREXEL International&#010;Perceptive Informatics UK Ltd&#010;8th Floor, Centre City Tower&#010;5/7 Hill Street&#010;Birmingham, UK, B5 4UA&#010;&#010;T +44.(0)121.616.5600&#010;Steve.Weston@PAREXEL.com&lt;mailto:Steve.Weston@PAREXEL.com&gt;&#010;www.PAREXEL.com&lt;http://www.parexel.com/&gt;&#010;&#010;[Description: Description: Description: Description: Description: Description: Description:&#010;Description: Description: Description: Description: Description: Description: C:\Users\MorrisoE\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Windows\Temporary&#010;Internet Files\Content.Word\R1_Logo.png]&lt;http://www.parexel.com/&gt;&#010;&#010;This communication, including any attachments, is intended only for the person or entity to&#010;which it is addressed and may contain confidential material. Re: release-plugin non-interactive release and system properties  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 09:22:29 GMT  
contents:- 
Hi Steve,&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;&gt; I’m confused as to how the version number in a pom file and the &#013;&#010;&gt; system properties like -DdevelopmentVersion=2.0-SNAPSHOT and -&#013;&#010;&gt; DreleaseVersion=1.2&#013;&#010;&gt; interact.&#013;&#010;&gt; When I run a mvn –B release:prepare –DdryRun=true –Dtag=1.2 -&#013;&#010;&gt; DdevelopmentVersion=2.0-SNAPSHOT -DreleaseVersion=1.2 for a pom.xml &#013;&#010;&gt; where &lt;version&gt;1.0&lt;/version&gt; and &lt;packaging&gt;jar&lt;/packaging&gt; the&#010;&#013;&#010;&gt; resulting jar file uses the pom version number not the command line &#013;&#010;&gt; version, i.e xxx-1.0.jar . Is this expected behaviour and if so what&#013;&#010;&gt; is the point of specifying the versions on the command line ?&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;AFAIK this will only work when you have a snapshot version in your pom, &#013;&#010;i.e. &lt;version&gt;1.0-SNAPSHOT&lt;/version&gt;.&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Regards&#013;&#010;&#013;&#010;Thorsten&#013;&#010;

Name  :- 
&quot;Omar@Gmail&quot; &lt;omarnet...@googlemail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Depend on a jar via another pom file  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 15:56:41 GMT  
contents:- 
I have a maven module (lets call it M) that requires aspectjrt but M&#010;already depends on another pom file that has aspectjrt within its&#010;dependency tree  like so:&#010;&#010;M -&gt;  middle pom -&gt; aspectjrt&#010;&#010;The problem is M would not compile unless I express the aspectjrt&#010;dependency directly in the M pom file, why?&#010;&#010;Is there a way for M to get apsectjrt via the middle pom without directly&#010;depending on aspectjrt?&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Nick Stolwijk &lt;nick.stolw...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Depend on a jar via another pom file  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 16:13:57 GMT  
contents:- 
That's called a transitive dependency and this blog[1] explains nicely why&#010;you shouldn't use those.&#010;&#010;[1] http://uglycoder.blogspot.nl/2008/04/flaw-with-mavens-transitive.html&#010;&#010;Hth,&#010;&#010;Nick Stolwijk&#010;&#010;~~~ Try to leave this world a little better than you found it and, when&#010;your turn comes to die, you can die happy in feeling that at any rate you&#010;have not wasted your time but have done your best ~~~&#010;&#010;Lord Baden-Powell&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Jan 8, 2014 at 4:56 PM, Omar@Gmail &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I have a maven module (lets call it M) that requires aspectjrt but M&#010;&gt; already depends on another pom file that has aspectjrt within its&#010;&gt; dependency tree  like so:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; M -&gt;  middle pom -&gt; aspectjrt&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The problem is M would not compile unless I express the aspectjrt&#010;&gt; dependency directly in the M pom file, why?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there a way for M to get apsectjrt via the middle pom without directly&#010;&gt; depending on aspectjrt?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Baptiste Mathus &lt;bmat...@batmat.net&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Depend on a jar via another pom file  
Date  :-
Wed, 15 Jan 2014 07:52:57 GMT  
contents:- 
Well, what "scope" are used here? Thus is a central element to manage&#010;transitivity.&#010;&#010;Btw, you should never rely on a dependency to get a dependency you're also&#010;using. You must redeclare it in your own pom. (mvn dependency:analyze can&#010;also help you here).&#010;&#010;Cheers&#010;Le 8 janv. 2014 16:59, "Omar@Gmail" &lt;omarnetbox@googlemail.com&gt; a écrit :&#010;&#010;&gt; I have a maven module (lets call it M) that requires aspectjrt but M&#010;&gt; already depends on another pom file that has aspectjrt within its&#010;&gt; dependency tree  like so:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; M -&gt;  middle pom -&gt; aspectjrt&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The problem is M would not compile unless I express the aspectjrt&#010;&gt; dependency directly in the M pom file, why?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is there a way for M to get apsectjrt via the middle pom without directly&#010;&gt; depending on aspectjrt?&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Laird Nelson &lt;ljnel...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
During plugin development, what is the context classloader set to?  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 18:50:41 GMT  
contents:- 
I have a plugin that I'm writing that needs to do two things during the&#010;course of its execution:&#010;Load a resource from the current project's classpath&#010;Load a resource from its own guts&#010;&#010;This is a fallback kind of thing: if the plugin can't find anything&#010;appropriate on the project classpath, then and only then do I want it to&#010;examine its own .jar file for the resource in question.&#010;&#010;My hunch is that there are probably already two classloaders set up for&#010;just this purpose.&#010;&#010;I am guessing (haven't tried yet) that the project classpath is probably&#010;visible to Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader().  Is that right?&#010;&#010;I'm also guessing (haven't tried yet) that from within my mojo&#010;this.getClass().getClassLoader() will return me a ClassLoader that is set&#010;up to be able to see my mojo's innards.  Is that right?&#010;&#010;Best,&#010;Laird&#010;&#010;-- &#010;http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Baptiste Mathus ...@batmat.net&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: During plugin development, what is the context classloader set to?  
Date  :-
Tue, 14 Jan 2014 13:20:57 GMT  
contents:- 
Hi,&#010;ClassWorlds is your friend if you need to do classloader fine-tuning.&#010;&#010;For example (taken in an old poc, so this should be adapted to use&#010;annotations etc.), something along the following would create a classpath&#010;with test scope elements.&#010;&#010;...&#010;public class SomeMojo extends AbstractMojo&#010;{&#010;        /**&#010;         * @parameter expression="${project.testClasspathElements}"&#010;         */&#010;        private&#010;List&lt;http://www.google.com/search?sitesearch=java.sun.com&amp;q=allinurl%3Aj2se%2F1+5+0%2Fdocs%2Fapi+List&gt;&#010;&lt;String &lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/String.html&gt;&gt;&#010; testProjectArtifacts;&#010;...&#010;        protected&#010;ClassLoader&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/ClassLoader.html&gt;&#010; getClassLoader()&#010;        {&#010;                try&#010;                {&#010;                        ClassWorld world = new ClassWorld();&#010;                        ClassRealm realm = world.newRealm("project");&#010;                        for&#010;(String&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/String.html&gt;&#010;artifact&#010;: testProjectArtifacts)&#010;                        {&#010;                                getLog().debug("Constituent : " + artifact);&#010;                                realm.addConstituent(new&#010;File&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/io/File.html&gt;&#010;(artifact).toURL());&#010;                        }&#010;                        return realm.getClassLoader();&#010;                }&#010;                catch&#010;(Exception&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/Exception.html&gt;&#010; e)&#010;                {&#010;                        throw new&#010;RuntimeException&lt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/RuntimeException.html&gt;&#010;("WTF", e);&#010;                }&#010;        }&#010;&#010;HTH&#010;&#010;&#010;2014/1/8 Laird Nelson &lt;ljnelson@gmail.com&gt;&#010;&#010;&gt; I have a plugin that I'm writing that needs to do two things during the&#010;&gt; course of its execution:&#010;&gt; Load a resource from the current project's classpath&#010;&gt; Load a resource from its own guts&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; This is a fallback kind of thing: if the plugin can't find anything&#010;&gt; appropriate on the project classpath, then and only then do I want it to&#010;&gt; examine its own .jar file for the resource in question.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; My hunch is that there are probably already two classloaders set up for&#010;&gt; just this purpose.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am guessing (haven't tried yet) that the project classpath is probably&#010;&gt; visible to Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader().  Is that right?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I'm also guessing (haven't tried yet) that from within my mojo&#010;&gt; this.getClass().getClassLoader() will return me a ClassLoader that is set&#010;&gt; up to be able to see my mojo's innards.  Is that right?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Best,&#010;&gt; Laird&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; http://about.me/lairdnelson&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Baptiste &lt;Batmat&gt; MATHUS - http://batmat.net&#010;&gt; Sauvez un arbre,&#010;&gt; Mangez un castor ! nbsp;! &lt;http://about.me/lairdnelson&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Todd Chapman &lt;t...@chaka.net&gt;  
Subject  :-
Need advice automating a Java test suite.  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 22:08:53 GMT  
contents:- 
Hello,&#010;&#010;We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&#010;Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&#010;The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;goal:&#010;&#010;mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db  (exec:java plugin&#010;to setup up a database)&#010;mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db           (exec:java&#010;plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db            (surefire&#010;plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db   (surefire plugin&#010;to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db        (exec:java&#010;plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;&#010;&#010;The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&#010;Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;-Todd&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Need advice automating a Java test suite.  
Date  :-
Wed, 08 Jan 2014 22:38:19 GMT  
contents:- 
Profiles are the path to madness.&#010;&#010;There are two ways I can see to tackle this:&#010;&#010;1. Use the invoker plugin to fork maven builds for each of your test steps&#010;&#010;Or&#010;&#010;2. Use a multi-module project so that the separate modules do the separate&#010;parts.&#010;&#010;The second is likely the more "maven way" but the 1st is not too far off,&#010;if done right, and probably the easiest to implement... Not too hard to&#010;refactor to #2 if you decide to later&#010;&#010;On Wednesday, 8 January 2014, Todd Chapman wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;&gt; suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;&gt; all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;&gt; Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;&gt; can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;&gt; goal:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db  (exec:java plugin&#010;&gt; to setup up a database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db           (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db            (surefire&#010;&gt; plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db   (surefire plugin&#010;&gt; to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db        (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;&gt; happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;&gt; articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Todd&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Sent from my phone&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Martin Gainty &lt;mgai...@hotmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
RE: Need advice automating a Java test suite.  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 00:44:32 GMT  
contents:- 
&#010;&#010;  &#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Date: Wed, 8 Jan 2014 17:08:53 -0500&#010;&gt; Subject: Need advice automating a Java test suite.&#010;&gt; From: todd@chaka.net&#010;&gt; To: users@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;&gt; suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;&gt; all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;&gt; Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;&gt; can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;&gt; goal:&#010;MG&gt;My initial thought was to bind each profile-group to different phases&#010;MG&gt;that way the reactor will govern the execution order of who gets executed first (mvn&#010;initialize),&#010;MG&gt;which profile gets executed second (mvn generate-test-sources) &#010;MG&gt;and finally last profile gets executed (mvn package)&#010;MG&gt;the problem is you have alot of testcases to run so perhaps running a string of profiles&#010;maybe the answer&#010; &#010;MG&gt;Profile1&#010;&gt; mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db (exec:java plugin&#010;&gt; to setup up a database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;MG&gt;Profile1&#010; &#010;MG&gt;Profile2&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db (surefire&#010;&gt; plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db (surefire plugin&#010;&gt; to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;MG&gt;Profile2&#010;&#010;MG&gt;Profile3&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;MG&gt;Profile3&#010; &#010;MG&gt;Off the top of my head i would setup a 'marker file' for the successful completion of&#010;each Profile&#010;MG&gt;When marker file from Profile1 exists trigger Profile 2 &#010;MG&gt;When marker file from Profile2 exists trigger Profile3&#010; &#010;MG&gt;mvn help:active-profiles -P Profile1,Profile2,Profile3 &#010;&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;&gt; happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;&gt; articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt; &#010;&gt; -Todd&#010;MG&gt;assuming the IDentifiers are unique (and presence of marker files are unique) synchronous&#010;profile execution *should* work&#010; &#009;&#009; &#009;   &#009;&#009;  &#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Need advice automating a Java test suite.  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 07:47:06 GMT  
contents:- 
It's little bit hard understanding all of the magic with your profiles and&#010;why you can''t combine them. But if I assume that you want to test your&#010;application with different configuration (different db, different&#010;configuration/properties, etc.) I suggest that you create a separate&#010;multi-module project for your testing. Each of the modules there would test&#010;ONE specific setup/config for the applicatation. You would bind the setup&#010;of the environment to the pre-integration-test phase and the tear down of&#010;the same to the post-integration-test phase. And then you use the&#010;maven-failsafe-plugin to execute all tests (for that app config) in the&#010;integration-test phase.&#010;&#010;If you have the same set of JUnit test classes to be used in all modules,&#010;you have these in a separate module which would create a test artifact that&#010;you re-use in the other modules. If you have a lot of the same pom config&#010;magics in the modules this can be moved to the pluginManagement section of&#010;the parent (more advanced Maven usage, do that last when everything already&#010;works).&#010;&#010;This will make it possible to build all modules for a complete test suite&#010;("mvn verify"). If you just want to test one setup/config you only build&#010;that module ("mvn verify").&#010;&#010;/Anders&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Jan 8, 2014 at 11:08 PM, Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;&gt; suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;&gt; all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;&gt; Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;&gt; can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;&gt; goal:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db  (exec:java plugin&#010;&gt; to setup up a database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db           (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db            (surefire&#010;&gt; plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db   (surefire plugin&#010;&gt; to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;&gt; mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db        (exec:java&#010;&gt; plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;&gt; happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;&gt; articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Todd&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Christofer Dutz &lt;christofer.d...@c-ware.de&gt;  
Subject  :-
AW: Need advice automating a Java test suite.  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 08:42:44 GMT  
contents:- 
Hi Todd,&#010;&#010;we use a combination of the cargo, antrun and surefire plugin for this. &#010;&#010;I dumped the pom for one of our Projects in my Confluence, so feel free to have a look:&#010;https://dev.c-ware.de/confluence/display/PUBLIC/Maven+setup+for+Integrationtesting&#010;&#010;In general we use:&#010;- Cargo to install/configure/deploy/start/stop the application.&#010;- Antrun is used to Setup the Database with Default values.&#010;- Surefire is configured to run tests ending with "IT" after starting the Container and before&#010;stopping it again.&#010;&#010;Perhaps this helps.&#010;&#010;Chris&#010;&#010;________________________________________&#010;Von: Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt;&#010;Gesendet: Mittwoch, 8. Januar 2014 23:08&#010;An: users@maven.apache.org&#010;Betreff: Need advice automating a Java test suite.&#010;&#010;Hello,&#010;&#010;We have a java multi-module project that has a somewhat painful to run test&#010;suite that I would like to get under control using Maven.&#010;&#010;Currently it takes 5 separate Maven commands to setup, run, and teardown&#010;all the tests and test databases. I'd like to get this down to one command.&#010;Also I would like this structured so that individual parts of the process&#010;can be run separately to aid in debugging problems.&#010;&#010;The pom has 1 profile for each part of the task, all bound to the "test"&#010;goal:&#010;&#010;mvn clean test -P test-setup-1,local-enterprise-test-db  (exec:java plugin&#010;to setup up a database)&#010;mvn test -P test-setup-2,local-enterprise-test-db           (exec:java&#010;plugin to setup up a 2nd database)&#010;mvn test -P test-design,local-enterprise-test-db            (surefire&#010;plugin to run a subset of the tests with maven properties set)&#010;mvn test -P test-transactional,local-enterprise-test-db   (surefire plugin&#010;to run a different subset of the tests with different maven properties set)&#010;mvn test -P test-tear-down,local-enterprise-test-db        (exec:java&#010;plugin to teardown the databases)&#010;&#010;&#010;The problem I am running into is how to get this organized so that it all&#010;happens with 1 command. It seems nearly unpossible.&#010;&#010;Can anyone offer any advice on how to accomplish this? Pointer to relevant&#010;articles, blog posts, stackoverflow questions would be most appreciated.&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;-Todd&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Paul Benedict &lt;pbened...@apache.org&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Skip copying resources  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 02:24:06 GMT  
contents:- 
Your problem is that, I think, you attached the execution to the "compile"&#010;phase. However, the "process-resources" phase already happened so you're&#010;not getting the right behavior. Attach to the correct phase.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Wed, Jan 8, 2014 at 4:05 PM, Kuo, Joncheng (HP Storage - MSDU) &lt;&#010;joncheng.kuo@hp.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; How do I skip copying resources? I try &lt;skip&gt; in &lt;configuration&gt; but it&#010;&gt; does not work.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;       &lt;plugin&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;artifactId&gt;maven-resources-plugin&lt;/artifactId&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;executions&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;execution&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;id&gt;copy-xxx&lt;/id&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;phase&gt;compile&lt;/phase&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;goals&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;goal&gt;copy-resources&lt;/goal&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;/goals&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;skip&gt;true&lt;/skip&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; &lt;outputDirectory&gt;${webapp.dir}/example/resources&lt;/outputDirectory&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;resources&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;resource&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;directory&gt;${webapp.dir}/resources&lt;/directory&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                     &lt;include&gt;**&lt;/include&gt;&#010;&gt;                   &lt;/includes&gt;&#010;&gt;                 &lt;/resource&gt;&#010;&gt;               &lt;/resources&gt;&#010;&gt;             &lt;/configuration&gt;&#010;&gt;           &lt;/execution&gt;&#010;&gt;         &lt;/executions&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Joncheng Kuo&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Cheers,&#010;Paul&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
&quot;Earl.Bennett&quot; &lt;earl.benn...@compuware.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Can't set Class-Path in jar using external manifest file  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 17:49:45 GMT  
contents:- 
I've been going around and around with this one for a few hours now.&#010;&#010;I am using Maven 3.1.1&#010;&#010;I created a jar file, and had the maven-jar-plugin generate the manifest&#010;file with the classPath for me. I am then able to sucessfully execute the&#010;jar file with java -jar.&#010;&#010;I then exported the manifest from the jar file to a file. I modified the&#010;pom.xml to not generate the classpath automatically, but to use the external&#010;manifest file I created.  When I try to run the resulting jar file using&#010;java -jar, I get a class not found extension. After some testing, I have&#010;concluded that the classpath in the manifest file is not being read.&#010;&#010;I exported the manifest from the non-working jar file to a second file.  I&#010;then compared the two files. The files are identical except for the position&#010;of the Built-By and Build-Jdk elements. In the maven generated manifest,&#010;these lines appear before the class path. In the manifest generated from the&#010;external file, these lines appear after the class path, even though they are&#010;defined before the class path in my external manifest file.&#010;&#010;The Class-Path elements themselves are identical!!&#010;&#010;The elements in the manifest are not supposed to be order sensitive as far&#010;as I know.&#010;&#010;So, I am at a loss.  I need to be able to define the classpath using an&#010;external manifest file because I need to be able to add directories to it,&#010;and I need to be able to control the order of the jar files in the&#010;classpath.&#010;&#010;I would very much appreciate any thoughts anyone may have on this.&#010;&#010;Earl&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Can-t-set-Class-Path-in-jar-using-external-manifest-file-tp5781041.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

mons-lang3-3.1.jar maven-common-artifact-filters-1.3.jar maven-projec&#010; t-2.2.1.jar maven-settings-2.2.1.jar maven-profile-2.2.1.jar maven-mo&#010; del-2.2.1.jar maven-artifact-manager-2.2.1.jar wagon-provider-api-1.0&#010; ata-3.0.4.jar plexus-component-annotations-1.5.5.jar aether-api-1.13.&#010; 1.jar aether-api-0.9.0.M2.jar aether-util-0.9.0.M2.jar junit-3.8.1.jar&#010; &#010;MG&gt;Note1: all of the target/classes were packaged into the jar&#010;MG&gt;Note2:the entities in 'Class-Path' are NOT in the jar&#010;MG&gt;For that effort I will need to build an "uber-jar"&#010;MG&gt;to build uber-jar (a jar with all the jars in classpath) I will need to implement maven-assembly-plugin&#010;MG&gt;with &lt;dependencySet&gt; specified with &lt;includes&gt;&lt;include&gt;jar1.jar&lt;/include&gt;&lt;include&lt;jar2.jar&gt;&lt;/includes&gt;&#010;MG&gt;http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-assembly-plugin/assembly.html#class_dependencySet&#010;MG&gt;does this help? &#009;&#009; Subject  :-
Re: Can't set Class-Path in jar using external manifest file  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 19:40:37 GMT  
contents:- 
Well... This is weird...&#010;&#010;I was generating an index.list file in my jar using&#010;&lt;archive&gt;&lt;index&gt;true&lt;/index&gt;&lt;/archive&gt;&#010;&#010;When I removed that, all my problems with the external manifest went away...&#010;&#010;It looks like there is some kind of problem with the index element and using&#010;an external manifest.&#010;&#010;My thanks to those who replied in an attempt to help me out.&#010;&#010;Earl&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;--&#010;View this message in context: http://maven.40175.n5.nabble.com/Can-t-set-Class-Path-in-jar-using-external-manifest-file-tp5781041p5781049.html&#010;Sent from the Maven - Users mailing list archive at Nabble.com.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Mirko Friedenhagen &lt;mfriedenha...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Options for producing class files with different compilers via Maven  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 21:13:41 GMT  
contents:- 
Hello,&#010;&#010;in the JaCoCo project (a Java code coverage library which uses a Java&#010;agent approach during runtime) we produce some false positives of&#010;uncovered code because of unreachable (e.g. private constructor of a&#010;util class) or synthetic java code (e.g. enum values()).&#010;&#010;As we inspect the class files only, we may not (or better do not want&#010;to) rely on parsing the source code for discovering such conditions.&#010;During some experiments we detected that different compilers (javac vs&#010;eclipse ecj) produce very different byte code in classes for the&#010;above. This might be the case for different versions of Sun/Oracle JDK&#010;or JDKs of other vendors as well. I already took a look at "Using&#010;Non-Javac Compilers" of the maven-compiler-plugin[1]&#010;&#010;Now my question:&#010;- What would be the best approach to produce JARs which contain class&#010;files of above mentioned false positives produced by the different&#010;compilers?&#010;- My first idea was to define a define a multi module project with a&#010;JAR module which will only produce a source jar, which will be&#010;unpacked as "generated-sources" in sibling modules which are then&#010;compiled by the different compilers.&#010;&#010;For additional ideas or caveats I would be grateful.&#010;&#010;&#010;Regards Mirko&#010;[0] https://github.com/jacoco/jacoco/wiki/FilteringOptions&#010;[1] http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-compiler-plugin/non-javac-compilers.html&#010;--&#010;http://illegalstateexception.blogspot.com/&#010;https://github.com/mfriedenhagen/ (http://osrc.dfm.io/mfriedenhagen)&#010;https://bitbucket.org/mfriedenhagen/&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Evgeny Mandrikov &lt;mandri...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: [jacoco-dev] Options for producing class files with different compilers via Maven  
Date  :-
Thu, 09 Jan 2014 21:35:14 GMT  
contents:- 
Hi,&#010;&#010;I have feeling that you ( "we" :) ) could simply use single module and&#010;define several executions of:&#010;&#010;   1. maven-compiler-plugin for compilation&#010;   2. maven-assembly-plugin to create JARs and attach them as additional&#010;   project artifacts&#010;&#010;But I never tried this.&#010;&#010;On Thu, Jan 9, 2014 at 10:13 PM, Mirko Friedenhagen &lt;mfriedenhagen@gmail.com&#010;&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; Hello,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; in the JaCoCo project (a Java code coverage library which uses a Java&#010;&gt; agent approach during runtime) we produce some false positives of&#010;&gt; uncovered code because of unreachable (e.g. private constructor of a&#010;&gt; util class) or synthetic java code (e.g. enum values()).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; As we inspect the class files only, we may not (or better do not want&#010;&gt; to) rely on parsing the source code for discovering such conditions.&#010;&gt; During some experiments we detected that different compilers (javac vs&#010;&gt; eclipse ecj) produce very different byte code in classes for the&#010;&gt; above. This might be the case for different versions of Sun/Oracle JDK&#010;&gt; or JDKs of other vendors as well. I already took a look at "Using&#010;&gt; Non-Javac Compilers" of the maven-compiler-plugin[1]&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Now my question:&#010;&gt; - What would be the best approach to produce JARs which contain class&#010;&gt; files of above mentioned false positives produced by the different&#010;&gt; compilers?&#010;&gt; - My first idea was to define a define a multi module project with a&#010;&gt; JAR module which will only produce a source jar, which will be&#010;&gt; unpacked as "generated-sources" in sibling modules which are then&#010;&gt; compiled by the different compilers.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; For additional ideas or caveats I would be grateful.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Regards Mirko&#010;&gt; [0] https://github.com/jacoco/jacoco/wiki/FilteringOptions&#010;&gt; [1]&#010;&gt; http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-compiler-plugin/non-javac-compilers.html&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; http://illegalstateexception.blogspot.com/&#010;&gt; https://github.com/mfriedenhagen/ (http://osrc.dfm.io/mfriedenhagen)&#010;&gt; https://bitbucket.org/mfriedenhagen/&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups&#010;&gt; "JaCoCo Developers" group.&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an&#010;&gt; email to jacoco-dev+unsubscribe@googlegroups.com.&#010;&gt; For more options, visit https://groups.google.com/groups/opt_out.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Best regards,&#010;Evgeny Mandrikov aka Godin &lt;http://godin.net.ru&gt;&#010;http://twitter.com/_godin_&#010;&#010;

Project Description Contest  
Date  :-
Fri, 10 Jan 2014 13:35:33 GMT  
contents:- 
I have added a Wiki page to track the submissions in this space also&#010;&#010;https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest&#010;&#010;&#010;On 6 January 2014 17:43, Lyons, Roy &lt;Roy.Lyons@cmegroup.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it&#010;&gt; says:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has&#010;&gt; great dependency management features."&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this is&#010;&gt; what it really is.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Project Description Contest  
Date  :-
Fri, 10 Jan 2014 14:01:41 GMT  
contents:- 
I like Roy Lyons contribution as an opening sentence.&#010;I think that the second and third sentence should be about what Maven is &#010;not what it is not. If we are going to compare it to Ant or Gradle, it &#010;should be done in a way that explains what Maven does not what it does &#010;not do.&#010;&#010;"Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has &#010;great dependency management features.  Maven uses a project object model &#010;to describe the dependencies and any special processes that are required &#010;to build the software. This encapsulates all of the knowledge required &#010;to repeatedly build the software as well as the supporting documentation &#010;and project reports. This frees the software developer from many of the &#010;routine tasks associated with software development. Maven enforces a set &#010;of best practices around version control and the software release &#010;process which encourages adherence to enterprise and project  standards &#010;regarding dependent libraries and collaborative development."&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;&#010;On 10/01/2014 8:35 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; I have added a Wiki page to track the submissions in this space also&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; On 6 January 2014 17:43, Lyons, Roy &lt;Roy.Lyons@cmegroup.com&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; on https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/New+Main+Site it&#010;&gt;&gt; says:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; We need a short and snappy description of what Maven is:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a software project management and comprehension tool."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Is just not an easy to understand description of what Maven is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I would like to submit my short description for review.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Apache Maven is a convention-over-configuration build tool which has&#010;&gt;&gt; great dependency management features."&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; I know that it does more than that - but I feel that at its core, this is&#010;&gt;&gt; what it really is.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010; Name  :- 
Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Project Description Contest  
Date  :-
Fri, 10 Jan 2014 15:05:25 GMT  
contents:- 
On 10 January 2014 14:01, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; If we are going to compare it to Ant or Gradle, it should be done in a way&#010;&gt; that explains what Maven does not what it does not do.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Did you even read the sentence I had in bold?&#010;&#010;&gt; *It is *not* our job to educate the reader about other build tools. Our&#010;job is to educate the reader about Maven*.&#010;&#010;The *reader* will be comparing Maven with Ant/Gradle/etc, so we need to&#010;give them the *information* they need. We do not need to (and in my opinion&#010;should not) mention Ant/Gradle/etc at all...&#010;&#010;To try and frame this better, consider a sentence like:&#010;&#010;"Maven takes a philosophy that most builds can be categorised based on the&#010;type of thing you are building and that there is a best way to build each&#010;type of thing, so you tell Maven the type of thing that you want to build&#010;rather than spelling out the exact build steps you want" (this specific is&#010;not a sentence I am suggesting as it is too long winded... a snappier&#010;version of this *could* be good though)&#010;&#010;Allows a reader who is used to the spelling out exact build steps (e.g.&#010;ANT/Make/etc) to identify one of the key differences in Maven's&#010;philosophy...&#010;&#010;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hC_r-dC4PqA Marmite^H^H^H^H^Hven you either&#010;love it or hate it!&#010;&#010;We are not going to convince the people who hate Maven that they love it,&#010;despite how ever much we provide a nice introduction or however much we&#010;improve our documentation... (though the fence sitters are up for grabs ;-)&#010;&#010;Just like no amount of waxing lyrical from the Marmite fans will convince&#010;me that it tastes nice... as far as I am concerned it is vile... I would&#010;rather starve to death than eat Marmite... but I can respect that some&#010;people like it.&#010;&#010;What we need to do is filter out the people who will hate Maven with as&#010;little time of theirs wasted... that way they will say "Maven you either&#010;love it or hate it" and move on, rather than spending hours ranting about&#010;how Maven is wrong, they can instead recognise that Maven has picked a&#010;different philosophy that is better for some people and worse for them.&#010;&#010;

Re: Project Description Contest

On 10/01/2014 10:05 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; On 10 January 2014 14:01, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; If we are going to compare it to Ant or Gradle, it should be done in a way&#010;&gt;&gt; that explains what Maven does not what it does not do.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; Did you even read the sentence I had in bold?&#010;&#010;Yes.&#010;I think that I was agreeing with that sentiment.&#010;&#010;&gt;&gt; *It is *not* our job to educate the reader about other build tools. Our&#010;&gt; job is to educate the reader about Maven*.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; The *reader* will be comparing Maven with Ant/Gradle/etc, so we need to&#010;&gt; give them the *information* they need. We do not need to (and in my opinion&#010;&gt; should not) mention Ant/Gradle/etc at all...&#010;&#010;I still think that a product comparison page/chart is a useful way to &#010;help a reader understand whether maven is a good choice in their &#010;circumstance.&#010;It should be on a separate page but could be linked from the front page.&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; To try and frame this better, consider a sentence like:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; "Maven takes a philosophy that most builds can be categorised based on the&#010;&gt; type of thing you are building and that there is a best way to build each&#010;&gt; type of thing, so you tell Maven the type of thing that you want to build&#010;&gt; rather than spelling out the exact build steps you want" (this specific is&#010;&gt; not a sentence I am suggesting as it is too long winded... a snappier&#010;&gt; version of this *could* be good though)&#010;Good start on a second paragraph for the opening page.&#010;It explains why Maven was built the way it was.&#010;One has to read between the lines to understand the "what's in it for &#010;me" but does hint at simplifying the build instructions through taking &#010;advantage of common patterns based on the output to be created.&#010;Perhaps if we focus on the benefits to this approach, we could add some &#010;framing around what you wrote to come up with a solid second paragraph.&#010;&#010;&gt; Allows a reader who is used to the spelling out exact build steps (e.g.&#010;&gt; ANT/Make/etc) to identify one of the key differences in Maven's&#010;&gt; philosophy...&#010;Could be incorporated into the text above.&#010;I am not sure that I would put the onus on the user to make the inference.&#010;We should just state the benefits - simplification, standardization, &#010;adherence to corporate/enterprise best practices - and how Maven/"Maven &#010;way" achieves these (by taking advantage of commonality of build flow, &#010;etc. as you stated above).&#010;&#010;I am not sure that I would mention the other build tools specifically here.&#010;I would save it for the comparison.&#010;&#010;&gt; http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hC_r-dC4PqA Marmite^H^H^H^H^Hven you either&#010;&gt; love it or hate it!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; We are not going to convince the people who hate Maven that they love it,&#010;&gt; despite how ever much we provide a nice introduction or however much we&#010;&gt; improve our documentation... (though the fence sitters are up for grabs ;-)&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Just like no amount of waxing lyrical from the Marmite fans will convince&#010;&gt; me that it tastes nice... as far as I am concerned it is vile... I would&#010;&gt; rather starve to death than eat Marmite... but I can respect that some&#010;&gt; people like it.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; What we need to do is filter out the people who will hate Maven with as&#010;&gt; little time of theirs wasted... that way they will say "Maven you either&#010;&gt; love it or hate it" and move on, rather than spending hours ranting about&#010;&gt; how Maven is wrong, they can instead recognise that Maven has picked a&#010;&gt; different philosophy that is better for some people and worse for them.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I see this discussion as part of a flame war that can be buried deeper &#010;in the site.&#010;I think that we should assume that a person who is arriving on the front &#010;page is coming looking for a solution not a range war.&#010;If they decide to use Ant, so be it.&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;
