Subject  :-
Re: Project Description Contest  
Date  :-
Fri, 10 Jan 2014 16:23:54 GMT  
contents:- 
On 10 January 2014 15:50, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; On 10/01/2014 10:05 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; On 10 January 2014 14:01, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt;&gt; &gt;wrote:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;  If we are going to compare it to Ant or Gradle, it should be done in a&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; way&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt; that explains what Maven does not what it does not do.&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;  Did you even read the sentence I had in bold?&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Yes.&#010;&gt; I think that I was agreeing with that sentiment.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  *It is *not* our job to educate the reader about other build tools. Our&#010;&gt;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; job is to educate the reader about Maven*.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; The *reader* will be comparing Maven with Ant/Gradle/etc, so we need to&#010;&gt;&gt; give them the *information* they need. We do not need to (and in my&#010;&gt;&gt; opinion&#010;&gt;&gt; should not) mention Ant/Gradle/etc at all...&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I still think that a product comparison page/chart is a useful way to help&#010;&gt; a reader understand whether maven is a good choice in their circumstance.&#010;&gt; It should be on a separate page but could be linked from the front page.&#010;&#010;&#010;I would link it from a FAQ page, not the front page... as understanding our&#010;choice of metrics to compare on requires some understanding of Maven&#010;first... otherwise a comparison that we think is fair to Maven will not be&#010;well understood.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; To try and frame this better, consider a sentence like:&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; "Maven takes a philosophy that most builds can be categorised based on the&#010;&gt;&gt; type of thing you are building and that there is a best way to build each&#010;&gt;&gt; type of thing, so you tell Maven the type of thing that you want to build&#010;&gt;&gt; rather than spelling out the exact build steps you want" (this specific is&#010;&gt;&gt; not a sentence I am suggesting as it is too long winded... a snappier&#010;&gt;&gt; version of this *could* be good though)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; Good start on a second paragraph for the opening page.&#010;&gt; It explains why Maven was built the way it was.&#010;&gt; One has to read between the lines to understand the "what's in it for me"&#010;&gt; but does hint at simplifying the build instructions through taking&#010;&gt; advantage of common patterns based on the output to be created.&#010;&gt; Perhaps if we focus on the benefits to this approach, we could add some&#010;&gt; framing around what you wrote to come up with a solid second paragraph.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  Allows a reader who is used to the spelling out exact build steps (e.g.&#010;&gt;&gt; ANT/Make/etc) to identify one of the key differences in Maven's&#010;&gt;&gt; philosophy...&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; Could be incorporated into the text above.&#010;&gt; I am not sure that I would put the onus on the user to make the inference.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;1. Don't preach to the reader... we should not tell them what to think&#010;&#010;2. Don't speak ill of others&#010;&#010;3. Don't assume that the reader cannot think for themselves.&#010;&#010;I am not saying we put the onus on the reader to make the inference. This&#010;could be the very first tool in this space that they have discovered.&#010;&#010;We should state our philosophy... give links to explain what we mean in the&#010;description, so that loaded terms can be understood by people who are&#010;unfamiliar with them... and by all means lets give links to&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; We should just state the benefits - simplification, standardization,&#010;&gt; adherence to corporate/enterprise best practices - and how Maven/"Maven&#010;&gt; way" achieves these (by taking advantage of commonality of build flow, etc.&#010;&gt; as you stated above).&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I am not sure that I would mention the other build tools specifically here.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;I am saying *no way* will we mention other build tools on the front page or&#010;in the project description.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; I would save it for the comparison.&#010;&#010;&#010;If we even need a comparison... but a comparison is not needed as much as a&#010;rebrand of the initial RX (or reader experience)&#010;&#010;Let's get the content needed to get a reader up and running and doing a few&#010;builds quickly that they can develop a feel for the Maven way... again that&#010;hits the theme of letting the reader find out - as quickly as we can let&#010;them - whether they love maven or hate it.&#010;&#010;The first level content should also hit things like the release plugin and&#010;project documentation&#010;&#010;The second level content should then be focused on more advanced things...&#010;&#010;* deviating from the conventions&#010;&#010;* writing simple plugins&#010;&#010;* forging a new path for a new packaging type&#010;&#010;The third level content, if we get that far, would be the more advanced&#010;plugin writing stuff...&#010;&#010;Only when we get that far should we start thinking about comparisons with&#010;other tooling&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hC_r-dC4PqA Marmite^H^H^H^H^Hven you&#010;&gt;&gt; either&#010;&gt;&gt; love it or hate it!&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; We are not going to convince the people who hate Maven that they love it,&#010;&gt;&gt; despite how ever much we provide a nice introduction or however much we&#010;&gt;&gt; improve our documentation... (though the fence sitters are up for grabs&#010;&gt;&gt; ;-)&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; Just like no amount of waxing lyrical from the Marmite fans will convince&#010;&gt;&gt; me that it tastes nice... as far as I am concerned it is vile... I would&#010;&gt;&gt; rather starve to death than eat Marmite... but I can respect that some&#010;&gt;&gt; people like it.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt; What we need to do is filter out the people who will hate Maven with as&#010;&gt;&gt; little time of theirs wasted... that way they will say "Maven you either&#010;&gt;&gt; love it or hate it" and move on, rather than spending hours ranting about&#010;&gt;&gt; how Maven is wrong, they can instead recognise that Maven has picked a&#010;&gt;&gt; different philosophy that is better for some people and worse for them.&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt;&gt;&#010;&gt; I see this discussion as part of a flame war that can be buried deeper in&#010;&gt; the site.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;Why would we want to put a flame war on our site?&#010;&#010;I think in the FAQ we could have a "comparison to other tools" section with&#010;things like&#010;&#010;Q: "I just want to specify the exact steps that Maven should build, like I&#010;can with Gradle. Why does Maven make this hard to do?"&#010;&#010;Q: "I just want to keep my dependencies in source control like Ant lets me.&#010;Why can't Maven use the dependencies that are in source control, forcing me&#010;to run a repository manager just to host them?"&#010;&#010;Such content sits best in a FAQ... but we should not knock these other&#010;tools. They are just as valid at building software as Maven is... look at&#010;the end result... the software is built.&#010;&#010;&gt;From our philosophy there is a big difference... there is a whole larger&#010;layer of trade-offs that we see... and from our point of view once you see&#010;the bigger picture that we see... well why would you use anything other&#010;than Maven... *but* that does not make us _right_... it just makes us&#010;self-consistent.&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; I think that we should assume that a person who is arriving on the front&#010;&gt; page is coming looking for a solution not a range war.&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;We don't know why somebody has landed on our front page... what we want to&#010;do is get the people who don't want to be here to move on as fast as&#010;possible so that they appreciate the fact that we have not wasted their&#010;time.&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; If they decide to use Ant, so be it.&#010;&#010;&#010;Maven... you either love it or hate it... I am happy with that&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; ---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;&gt; To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt; For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Value of a prodyct comparison  
Date  :-
Fri, 10 Jan 2014 15:02:07 GMT  
contents:- 
I am not sure that I agree with this section of &#010;https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest*&#010;"Note: *this does not preclude us from including a "feature comparison &#010;matrix" page somewhere in our site... but we should recognise that such &#010;a matrix would likely be biased by our philosophy, which most likely &#010;negates the utility of hosting such a page on our site. Let us leave the &#010;feature comparison matrices to those that have no axe to grind (and &#010;spend our energy ensuring that their matrices are fair to us, just as &#010;other solutions in this space should be doing for the representation of &#010;their tools on such matrices)"&#010;&#010;There may be some value is writing the comparison from a Maven point of &#010;view.&#010;It does give a chance to describe where there are differences and why &#010;they are important from the POV of the "Maven way". Maven is based on &#010;certain beliefs about the way software should be developed and built. As &#010;most politicians can tell you, it is better to define yourself than have &#010;someone else define you.&#010;It is most uncertain that third parties will give the same weighting to &#010;the value of certain practices and features that the Maven community would.&#010;It is clear from the discussions in this forum, that it is easy to get &#010;off to a shaky start when first trying to use Maven. A person doing a &#010;quick evaluation of development tools could easily bring with them some &#010;assumptions about software development processes and come up with a very &#010;distorted view of Maven.&#010;&#010;I think that an accurate product comparison written from the maven POV &#010;is fair and useful for someone coming to Maven for the first time. It &#010;will highlight things that Maven does that other systems don't do as &#010;well and there is no reason to exclude things where Ant is better and &#010;explain why the Maven community does not consider that a deal breaker.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;  

================

Name  :- 
Stephen Connolly &lt;stephen.alan.conno...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Value of a prodyct comparison  
Date  :-
Fri, 10 Jan 2014 15:19:09 GMT  
contents:- 
On 10 January 2014 15:02, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; I am not sure that I agree with this section of https://cwiki.apache.org/&#010;&gt; confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest*&#010;&gt; "Note: *this does not preclude us from including a "feature comparison&#010;&gt; matrix" page somewhere in our site... but we should recognise that such a&#010;&gt; matrix would likely be biased by our philosophy, which most likely negates&#010;&gt; the utility of hosting such a page on our site. Let us leave the feature&#010;&gt; comparison matrices to those that have no axe to grind (and spend our&#010;&gt; energy ensuring that their matrices are fair to us, just as other solutions&#010;&gt; in this space should be doing for the representation of their tools on such&#010;&gt; matrices)"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; There may be some value is writing the comparison from a Maven point of&#010;&gt; view.&#010;&gt; It does give a chance to describe where there are differences and why they&#010;&gt; are important from the POV of the "Maven way". Maven is based on certain&#010;&gt; beliefs about the way software should be developed and built. As most&#010;&gt; politicians can tell you, it is better to define yourself than have someone&#010;&gt; else define you.&#010;&gt; It is most uncertain that third parties will give the same weighting to&#010;&gt; the value of certain practices and features that the Maven community would.&#010;&gt; It is clear from the discussions in this forum, that it is easy to get off&#010;&gt; to a shaky start when first trying to use Maven. A person doing a quick&#010;&gt; evaluation of development tools could easily bring with them some&#010;&gt; assumptions about software development processes and come up with a very&#010;&gt; distorted view of Maven.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I think that an accurate product comparison written from the maven POV is&#010;&gt; fair and useful for someone coming to Maven for the first time. It will&#010;&gt; highlight things that Maven does that other systems don't do as well and&#010;&gt; there is no reason to exclude things where Ant is better and explain why&#010;&gt; the Maven community does not consider that a deal breaker.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;Such a comparison should not be on the first page people land on. If we can&#010;come up with a comparison that we think is fair to all, even if comparing&#010;on our best feature set, then that is fine. The point I was making in that&#010;"note" is that excluding mentioning the competition in the project&#010;description does not mean we are excluding mentioning them at all. The&#010;second point is that there is an argument against having such a comparison&#010;chart anyway... but if we have one that we think is fair to all and&#010;reflects our philosophy then that is fine... not priority #1, #2 or #3 for&#010;a re-design of the maven site&#010;&#010;&#010;&gt; Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; --&#010;&gt; Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt; President&#010;&gt; Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt; email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt; skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt; phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Ron Wheeler &lt;rwhee...@artifact-software.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Value of a prodyct comparison  
Date  :-
Fri, 10 Jan 2014 16:06:15 GMT  
contents:- 
I agree. No product comparison on the first page.&#010;&#010;If one is written, it should be accurate and fair but, of course, it &#010;will focus on things that the Maven community values and that reflect &#010;the most common development practices as the community sees them.&#010;&#010;It should be written in such a way that people who should use Ant will &#010;understand why Maven is not the right choice and people who should use &#010;Gradle will understand what they are gaining and what they are losing. &#010;(Marmite haters should be allowed to go in peace with our blessing)&#010;It should not be written in a way that starts a flame war or is &#010;unhelpful to the developer who reads it.&#010;&#010;Ron&#010;&#010;On 10/01/2014 10:19 AM, Stephen Connolly wrote:&#010;&gt; On 10 January 2014 15:02, Ron Wheeler &lt;rwheeler@artifact-software.com &#010;&gt; &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     I am not sure that I agree with this section of&#010;&gt;     https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/Project+Description+Contest*&#010;&gt;     "Note: *this does not preclude us from including a "feature&#010;&gt;     comparison matrix" page somewhere in our site... but we should&#010;&gt;     recognise that such a matrix would likely be biased by our&#010;&gt;     philosophy, which most likely negates the utility of hosting such&#010;&gt;     a page on our site. Let us leave the feature comparison matrices&#010;&gt;     to those that have no axe to grind (and spend our energy ensuring&#010;&gt;     that their matrices are fair to us, just as other solutions in&#010;&gt;     this space should be doing for the representation of their tools&#010;&gt;     on such matrices)"&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     There may be some value is writing the comparison from a Maven&#010;&gt;     point of view.&#010;&gt;     It does give a chance to describe where there are differences and&#010;&gt;     why they are important from the POV of the "Maven way". Maven is&#010;&gt;     based on certain beliefs about the way software should be&#010;&gt;     developed and built. As most politicians can tell you, it is&#010;&gt;     better to define yourself than have someone else define you.&#010;&gt;     It is most uncertain that third parties will give the same&#010;&gt;     weighting to the value of certain practices and features that the&#010;&gt;     Maven community would.&#010;&gt;     It is clear from the discussions in this forum, that it is easy to&#010;&gt;     get off to a shaky start when first trying to use Maven. A person&#010;&gt;     doing a quick evaluation of development tools could easily bring&#010;&gt;     with them some assumptions about software development processes&#010;&gt;     and come up with a very distorted view of Maven.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     I think that an accurate product comparison written from the maven&#010;&gt;     POV is fair and useful for someone coming to Maven for the first&#010;&gt;     time. It will highlight things that Maven does that other systems&#010;&gt;     don't do as well and there is no reason to exclude things where&#010;&gt;     Ant is better and explain why the Maven community does not&#010;&gt;     consider that a deal breaker.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Such a comparison should not be on the first page people land on. If &#010;&gt; we can come up with a comparison that we think is fair to all, even if &#010;&gt; comparing on our best feature set, then that is fine. The point I was &#010;&gt; making in that "note" is that excluding mentioning the competition in &#010;&gt; the project description does not mean we are excluding mentioning them &#010;&gt; at all. The second point is that there is an argument against having &#010;&gt; such a comparison chart anyway... but if we have one that we think is &#010;&gt; fair to all and reflects our philosophy then that is fine... not &#010;&gt; priority #1, #2 or #3 for a re-design of the maven site&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     Ron&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;     -- &#010;&gt;     Ron Wheeler&#010;&gt;     President&#010;&gt;     Artifact Software Inc&#010;&gt;     email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;&gt;     &lt;mailto:rwheeler@artifact-software.com&gt;&#010;&gt;     skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;&gt;     phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;&#010;-- &#010;Ron Wheeler&#010;President&#010;Artifact Software Inc&#010;email: rwheeler@artifact-software.com&#010;skype: ronaldmwheeler&#010;phone: 866-970-2435, ext 102&#010;&#010;&#010;

Todd Chapman &lt;t...@chaka.net&gt;  
Subject  :-
Running cleanup code after tests in multi-module project.  
Date  :-
Fri, 10 Jan 2014 21:59:36 GMT  
contents:- 
What is the best way to run cleanup code after testing a multi-module&#010;project?&#010;&#010;Basically, post-integration-test for the entire reactor. Is the best way to&#010;create another module that is last to run in the reactor order?&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;-Todd&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Anders Hammar &lt;and...@hammar.net&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Running cleanup code after tests in multi-module project.  
Date  :-
Mon, 13 Jan 2014 19:48:44 GMT  
contents:- 
IMO each Maven project should be independent, even test projects. So there&#010;should be cleanup code in each module.&#010;&#010;&#010;On Fri, Jan 10, 2014 at 10:59 PM, Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; What is the best way to run cleanup code after testing a multi-module&#010;&gt; project?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Basically, post-integration-test for the entire reactor. Is the best way to&#010;&gt; create another module that is last to run in the reactor order?&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; Thanks!&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; -Todd&#010;&gt;&#010;&#010;

Name  :- 
Todd Chapman &lt;t...@chaka.net&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Running cleanup code after tests in multi-module project.

Tue, 14 Jan 2014 00:19:39 GMT  
contents:- 
Anders,&#010;&#010;I agree with you. Unfortunately I inherited this project and there is setup&#010;required that is identical for each module and is expensive to set up and&#010;tear down. It will take time to refactor the tests to be less expensive to&#010;prepare.&#010;&#010;In the mean time I'm looking for ways to deal with situation I have now.&#010;&#010;Thanks!&#010;&#010;-Todd&#010;&#010;&#010;On Mon, Jan 13, 2014 at 2:48 PM, Anders Hammar &lt;anders@hammar.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&#010;&gt; IMO each Maven project should be independent, even test projects. Name  :- 
Barrie Treloar &lt;baerr...@gmail.com&gt;  
Subject  :-
Re: Running cleanup code after tests in multi-module project.  
Date  :-
Tue, 14 Jan 2014 00:45:14 GMT  
contents:- 
On 14 January 2014 10:49, Todd Chapman &lt;todd@chaka.net&gt; wrote:&#010;&gt; Anders,&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; I agree with you. Unfortunately I inherited this project and there is setup&#010;&gt; required that is identical for each module and is expensive to set up and&#010;&gt; tear down. It will take time to refactor the tests to be less expensive to&#010;&gt; prepare.&#010;&gt;&#010;&gt; In the mean time I'm looking for ways to deal with situation I have now.&#010;&#010;It sounds like these tests are not unit tests if they need any&#010;setup/teardown of external systems.&#010;These are integration tests.&#010;&#010;It would make more sense to move these tests into one integration-test module.&#010;You then get your one setup/teardown and all the tests are together.&#010;&#010;It should be a matter of moving things around in version control&#010;rather than having to refactor the tests.&#010;&#010;---------------------------------------------------------------------&#010;To unsubscribe, e-mail: users-unsubscribe@maven.apache.org&#010;For additional commands, e-mail: users-help@maven.apache.org&#010;&#010;&#010;
